commit_message:
Separation of Evaluator and InitializationStatus from ConsistencyEnforcer

Refactoring before parallel evaluator, evaluator is currently held by consistency to be used during the initialization step.
Initialization code moved to InitializationStatus and init thread is now started from the VitrageGraphService.

Change-Id: I551b5d863da0e875b08d3f45754d4be64707fc0a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/vitrage refs/changes/67/479867/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: evaluator, entity_graph, initialization_status): self.evaluator = evaluator self.initialization_status = initialization_status def initializing_process(self): try: LOG.info('Consistency Initializing Process - Started') if not self._wait_for_action( self.initialization_status.is_received_all_end_messages): LOG.error('Maximum retries for consistency initializator ' 'were done') LOG.info('All end messages were received') self.evaluator.enabled = True timestamp = str(utcnow()) all_vertices = self.graph.get_vertices() self._run_evaluator(all_vertices) self._wait_for_processing_evaluator_events() self._mark_old_deduced_alarms_as_deleted(timestamp) self.initialization_status.status = \ self.initialization_status.FINISHED LOG.info('Consistency Initializing Process - Finished') except Exception as e: LOG.exception('Error in deleting vertices from entity_graph: %s', e) def _find_old_deduced_alarms(self, timestamp): query = { 'and': [ {'==': {VProps.VITRAGE_CATEGORY: EntityCategory.ALARM}}, {'==': {VProps.VITRAGE_TYPE: VITRAGE_DATASOURCE}}, {'<': {VProps.VITRAGE_SAMPLE_TIMESTAMP: timestamp}} ] } return self.graph.get_vertices(query_dict=query) def _run_evaluator(self, vertices): start_time = time.time() for vertex in vertices: self.evaluator.process_event(None, vertex, True) LOG.info('Run Evaluator on %s items - took %s', str(len(vertices)), str(time.time() - start_time)) def _wait_for_processing_evaluator_events(self): # wait for multiprocessing to put the events in the queue time.sleep(1) self._wait_for_action(self.evaluator_queue.empty) def _mark_old_deduced_alarms_as_deleted(self, timestamp): old_deduced_alarms = self._find_old_deduced_alarms(timestamp) self._push_events_to_queue(old_deduced_alarms, GraphAction.DELETE_ENTITY)

subject: skip redirects when code name matches service type
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-07-14 17:20:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals/commit/5a2c84c0f59818f0a208bd521a716a4f4438a3dc', 'message': "skip redirects when code name matches service type

The ec2-api project docs aren't accessible because /ec2-api/ redirects
to /ec2-api/latest/ (due to the rule about project URLs without a
series) and /ec2-api/.* redirects to /ec2-api/latest/ (due to the rule
for service types). The combination ensures that accessing
docs.o.o/ec2-api/ results in an infinite redirect loop. This change
breaks the loop by skiping the service type rule when the service type
and project name match.

Change-Id: I79e869b12cbd33f79cd1455d9aa26ec5a6642429
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
skip redirects when code name matches service type

The ec2-api project docs aren't accessible because /ec2-api/ redirects
to /ec2-api/latest/ (due to the rule about project URLs without a
series) and /ec2-api/.* redirects to /ec2-api/latest/ (due to the rule
for service types). The combination ensures that accessing
docs.o.o/ec2-api/ results in an infinite redirect loop. This change
breaks the loop by skiping the service type rule when the service type
and project name match.

Change-Id: I79e869b12cbd33f79cd1455d9aa26ec5a6642429
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/04/484004/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: {%- if project.type == 'service' and project.service_type and (project.service_type|lower != project.name) %}

commit_message:
require all projects to have published docs

Before we add projects to the project list page, ensure that they have
already published documentation for the relevant series.

Change-Id: Ia81a775c95caa1b3a32640abb86c1beb56697d6e
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

added_lines: # NOTE(dhellmann): List of tuple of flag name and URL template. None # for the flag name means always apply the URL, otherwise look for a # True value associated with the flag in the project data. (None, 'https://docs.openstack.org/{name}/{series}/'), if flag is None: flag_val = True else: flag_val = project.get(flag, False) flag or 'home page check', project['name'], url, status,
deleted_lines: flag_val = project.get(flag, False) flag, project['name'], url, status,

commit_message:
Allow modprobing from cinder-volume container

When using LVM/iSCSI backend, cinder-volume tries to modprobe configfs
module. We need the modules dir bind mounted for this to succeed.

Co-Authored-By: Gorka Eguileor <geguileo@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I7bfeaa66915e663726acdf3458db80821fbd3d6b
Closes-Bug: #1701321

commit_message:
LVM in cinder-volume container without udev

Disabling udev usage from LVM seems to be the only observed working
way of running containerized cinder-volume with local LVM backend.

I didn't come across reports that not using udev would have negative
impact on the functionality.

Additional info at
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/docker-user/n4Xtvsb4RAw

Change-Id: I491795deab0c37d1bad3b50524481e0b76529667
Depends-On: I1bf395a6228dba66fa6bf9b8bcc9f3ac3d922a49
Closes-Bug: #1700982

Fixing string formatting bug in log message.

The first named formatting parameter was missing the 's' suffix
this caused python to throw an error.

Implement API Keys as a new credential type in order to improve security
by limiting access and not embedding user account credentials in configuration
files. API Keys are intended to empower consumers of clouds to have a
mechanism to safely use the API without compromising their credentials,
and to allow cloud-native applications that need to make API calls the
ability to do so without needing to have the complete account
credentials embedded.

commit_message:
Application Credentials for application authn

Implement Applicataion Credentials as a new credential type in order to
improve security by limiting access and not embedding user account
credentials in configuration files. Application Credentials are intended
to empower consumers of clouds to have a mechanism to safely use the API
without compromising their credentials, and to allow cloud-native
applications that need to make API calls the ability to do so without
needing to have the complete account credentials embedded.

Partially-implements: blueprint application-credentials
Co-Authored-By: Jamie Lennox <jamielennox@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Monty Taylor <mordred@inaugust.com>
Co-Authored-By: Colleen Murphy <colleen.murphy@suse.com>
Change-Id: I58a345513dadbacd4166f7d4a4b8d11775ccc736
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/15/450415/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========== Access Keys =========== `bp access-keys <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/access-keys>`_ Implement access keys as a new credential type in order to improve security by limiting access and not embedding user credentials in configuration files. Problem Description =================== As an OpenStack user, I want to create routine jobs that programmatically request a token and make API calls for resources in my project. To accomplish this, one will typically store user credentials in a configuration file so that scripts can access the OpenStack API. Having user credentials in configuration files and/or embedding them into a virtual machine, creates a potential security risk. Likewise, by using a user's credentials, the jobs or scripts will have all of a user's access and likely, more access than needed. Similarly, service users are stored in configuration files. For example, the nova service user is currently in the configuration of every nova-api, nova-compute and neutron configuration file. At run time, the service uses these credentials to perform service-to-service actions. From a security perspective, it can be considered unfavorable to have user credentials written to a file on disk, especially if the user has administrator privileges on a project. Ideally, we'd like to apply the principle of least privilege (POLP), and limit access to the minimum level required to complete the job. Proposed Change =============== Implement access keys as a new password credential type to be used by scripts/tools/3rd party applications. Access keys will be restricted to a project and have limited access (only a subset of a user's roles). Access key requirements: * Must be immutable * Allow for limits, e.g. 5 access keys per user. * Can only contain roles that the user has on a project. * The key value is only exposed once, in the create key API response. * Cannot be able to create or delete access keys * Should support the ability to expire * Should have a description field By default, any user with at least a member role on a project should be able to list, add, and delete access keys for their account. For example, adding an access key: .. code:: javascript POST /v3/users/{user_id}/access_keys { "access_key": { "description": "Backup job...", "expires_at": "2017-11-06T15:32:17.000000", "project_id": "9f3d967a326d4ec28f1ae9d57e6c7bc6" "role_ids": ["33cb539f3ebd4562bf6f0fb63b588749"] } } Response example: .. code:: javascript { "access_key": { "id": "98a2cffef26a4ada91c2b55618c60bd8", "value": "bc16f9a13f62442ca596f9f371ce5fd5", "description": "Backup job...", "expires_at": "2017-11-06T15:32:17.000000", "project_id": "9f3d967a326d4ec28f1ae9d57e6c7bc6" "role_ids": ["33cb539f3ebd4562bf6f0fb63b588749"] } } The id in the response is the access key identifier and would be returned in get or list API calls. However, the value would be a random string and only returned via the create API call. Once created, the access key value can then be used as an authentication credential to request a scoped token. For example: .. code:: javascript POST /v3/auth/tokens { "auth": { "identity": { "methods": [ "access_key" ], "access_key": { "id": "98a2cffef26a4ada91c2b55618c60bd8", "value": "a49670c3c18b9e079b9cfaf51634f563dc8ae3070db2c..." } } } } We can validate the access key by matching a hash of the key value associated with the id using passlib, similar to how we do password authentication. We would also validate the access key roles, ensuring that the roles associated with the access key are still assigned to the user. This improves security as access keys will have limited access; can be rotated and securely stored in configuration files. Especially for users that do not have privileges to create users with limited access, but do have a need to provide authentication credentials to a script or a 3rd party application. And as an alternative for service users, you could create a single service user with an access key for each service. Or, for example, create a root nova user and then give each nova instance it's own access key. Services can then replace username/password with access key id/value in their configuration files, so that the root service account credentials are never exposed. That being said, you can already limit access for service users, so it's not the main use case here, but gives operators additional options. Alternatives ------------ Continue with trusts and using OAuth authentication. The OAuth work flow is similar to that of access keys and it can be worked on and improved. Security Impact --------------- This would have a positive security impact: * Instead of having a service user for each service, all services can use a single service account. This decreases the attack vector of gaining access to privileged operations by reducing the number of accounts to attack. * User names and passwords are kept out of configuration files. While access keys are still extremely sensitive, if compromised they do not allow attackers to glean service user password conventions from configuration. * Access keys have limited access; only the access required to complete the job. * Access keys can be gracefully rotated out of use and deleted periodically, allowing operators another way to prevent compromised service accounts in combination with regular password rotation. That being said, there is an inherent risk with adding a new credential type and changing authentication details. One such risk would be the allowing of many credentials for the same user account. Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- End users that have applications that monitor or interact with OpenStack services should be able to leverage this feature to improve the overall security of consuming applications. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Deployers should notice the following maintenance improvements: * Operators only need to enforce security on a single service account instead of multiple. * Password rotation policies for service account no longer requires redeploying service configuration files. Once a password is changes for the service, the existing access keys in the various service configuration files will still work. * Operators can gracefully rotate access keys through a deployment. A set of services can use two different access keys at the same time allowing a smooth migration. Once all services are using the new access key, the old access key can be deleted. With service accounts and passwords, this would require changing the password of the service user and redeploying the service configuration files in a short time window to ensure service uptime. Access keys allow for service uptime while keeping the identity of the service user protected and secure. Developer Impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: - Ron De Rose Other contributors: - Anthony Washington - TBD Work Items ---------- 1. Develop backend to support access keys 2. Implement API, business logic, and validation for CRUD operations 3. Add new access key authentication plugin 4. Documentation 5. Notify deployment projects about using access keys (Devstack, OpenStack-Ansible, Tripleo, OpenStack Puppet, etc) Dependencies ============ None Documentation Impact ==================== The documentation team, along with the documentation liaison for keystone will have to update the installation guide to account for access keys and service accounts. The user guides should also be updated to reflect the ability for users to use access keys for application authentication. References ========== None

commit_message:
Update test.attr to decorators.attr

Tempest has moved their attr decorator to tempest.lib [0]. This
change updates all test.attr decorators to the new location,
removing deprecation warnings.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/456236/

Closes-Bug: #1683952
Change-Id: Ia0d47ab60f57ae0e1eee65527297f14afce378e0

commit_message:
Remove support for py34.

The gating on python 3.4 is restricted to <= Mitaka. This is due to
the change from Ubuntu Trusty to Xenial, where only python3.5 is
available. There is no need to continue to keep these settings.

Change-Id: Iec20a052df14c3a6c882012488c36ea3eb0a939a

commit_message:
Add support for next_min_version and not_before

The API-WG just approved the spec for version discovery documents to
optionally provide "next_min_version" and "not_before" information.

  http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/microversion_specification.html#version-discovery

The intended use of these is to communicate that at a point in the
future the service plans to raise the minimum microversion. It can't say
when that will happen, as a service does not know when deployers will
decide to upgrade their services. But it can communicate the earliest
date it's possible to happen, which would be the first date the service
itself would raise the minimum.

This can be used to emit warnings to users who are using a microversion
less than the next_min_version and to tell them how long they have to
think about it.

Currently keystoneauth will not consume these for that purpose. This
patch is merely about collecting the information from the discovery
document if it is there so a consumer can take action on it if they
wish.

Change-Id: Ibc404ef55eeae721a0d1d16e4e3e51ad77b5a75c

Change-Id: I73c3f071f28ee5c7f5d8f7a692a233fbd19f9260
Closes-Bug: #1620214
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-09-23 08:39:50.000000000', 'files': ['glance_store/_drivers/sheepdog.py', 'glance_store/tests/unit/test_sheepdog_store.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance_store/commit/2497c6f60137eda08fab76405e2f6ad646dff02b', 'message': 'Sheepdog: fix command execution failure

Sheepdog driver uses oslo_concurrency.processutils.execute
to execute the collie command.
Until the commit 79532ea599cd0226e7176c6c7d59e04ee3b1a8ff,
the driver uses execute in shell=True mode. In this mode,
the arguments of execute can be a string of command arguments.
But in default shell=False mode, the arguments of execute
should be a sequence of command arguments.

A minimum example:

>>> processutils.execute('echo hoge', shell=True)
('hoge\n', '')

>>> processutils.execute('echo hoge')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/

    errread, errwrite)

    line 1327, in _execute_child
    raise child_exception
OSError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory

>>> processutils.execute('echo', 'hoge')
('hoge\n', '')

Change-Id: I73c3f071f28ee5c7f5d8f7a692a233fbd19f9260
Closes-Bug: #1620214

commit_message:
Sheepdog: fix command execution failure

Sheepdog driver uses oslo_concurrency.processutils.execute
to execute the collie command.
Until the commit 79532ea599cd0226e7176c6c7d59e04ee3b1a8ff,
the driver uses execute in shell=True mode. In this mode,
the arguments of execute can be a string of command arguments.
But in default shell=False mode, the arguments of execute
should be a sequence of command arguments.

A minimum example:

>>> processutils.execute('echo hoge', shell=True)
('hoge\n', '')

>>> processutils.execute('echo hoge')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/
         oslo_concurrency/processutils.py", line 363, in execute
    env=env_variables)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/subprocess.py", line 710, in __init__
    errread, errwrite)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/subprocess.py",
    line 1327, in _execute_child
    raise child_exception
OSError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory

>>> processutils.execute('echo', 'hoge')
('hoge\n', '')

Change-Id: I73c3f071f28ee5c7f5d8f7a692a233fbd19f9260
Closes-Bug: #1620214

subject: [placement] fix 500 error when allocating to bad class
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-07-15 17:54:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/13de845766eecc7dfa39e796521ebbecea8076bf', 'message': '[placement] fix 500 error when allocating to bad class

Adjust exception handling when calling set_allocations so that a
KeyError in the usage_map raises an InvalidInventory. When making
allocations against against a resource provider with >1 resource classes
and where one of those resource classes does not have inventory on the
provider, we can attempt to get info out of the usage_map that is not
there, and get a KeyError. This catches the KeyError and turns it into
an InvalidInventory which eventually results in a 409 response,
consistent with other responses to bad allocations. Since this is fixing
a 500, no microversion required.

Change-Id: I52fa02b56f8e62dfa206a3969a99fab250508760
Closes-Bug: #1704574
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-07-16 11:09:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/69ca185019b42633e56924b7ef76a245d386e53f', 'message': '[placement] fix 500 error when allocating to bad class

Adjust exception handling when calling set_allocations so that a
KeyError in the usage_map raises an InvalidInventory. When making
allocations against against a resource provider with >1 resource classes
and where one of those resource classes does not have inventory on the
provider, we can attempt to get info out of the usage_map that is not
there, and get a KeyError. This catches the KeyError and turns it into
an InvalidInventory which eventually results in a 409 response,
consistent with other responses to bad allocations. Since this is fixing
a 500, no microversion required.

Change-Id: I52fa02b56f8e62dfa206a3969a99fab250508760
Closes-Bug: #1704574

allocations against a resource provider with >1 resource classes
and where one of those resource classes does not have inventory on the
provider, we can attempt to get info out of the usage_map that is not
there, and get a KeyError. This catches the KeyError and turns it into
an InvalidInventory which eventually results in a 409 response,
consistent with other responses to bad allocations. Since this is fixing
a 500, no microversion required.

Change-Id: I52fa02b56f8e62dfa206a3969a99fab250508760
Closes-Bug: #1704574
'}]
commit_message:
[placement] fix 500 error when allocating to bad class

Adjust exception handling when calling set_allocations so that a
KeyError in the usage_map raises an InvalidInventory. When making
allocations against a resource provider with >1 resource classes
and where one of those resource classes does not have inventory on the
provider, we can attempt to get info out of the usage_map that is not
there, and get a KeyError. This catches the KeyError and turns it into
an InvalidInventory which eventually results in a 409 response,
consistent with other responses to bad allocations. Since this is fixing
a 500, no microversion required.

Change-Id: I52fa02b56f8e62dfa206a3969a99fab250508760
Closes-Bug: #1704574

commit_message:
Add swarm-mode driver

* add swarm-mode config
* remove etcd, flannel, discovery_url, swift_registry
* add swarm-mode COE obj
* add functional test, create cluster, create/remove
  service and delete cluster.

Co-Authored-By: ArchiFleKs <kevin.lefevre@osones.io>
Implements: blueprint swarm-mode-support
Change-Id: Iba177be167cb3a3866441d5f42670171f26c5a86

commit_message:
Introduce form-field directive

The form-field directive abstracts the data, presentation, and operation of
a form field into a reusable component. It is intended to improve
maintainability and consistency. Form-field is currently being used to
create and edit ports, however, the goal is to use it throughout the
Ironic-UI. Componentizing form elements will also make it easier to
move to other libraries such as SchemaForm should we decide to do that.

Change-Id: I4cd84cd0840878b3dc34afe9def8e7f94be46fd0

commit_message:
Reorganised api-ref index page

Currently in the keystone API documentation page located at,
https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/index.html
all the sections and sub-sections appear at the same depth.
This makes the ordering very untidy and confusing.

This patch reorganises the appearance of sections and
sub-sections at the index page.

Change-Id: I55ae0102236805591e653c153618dec2af510c63
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/09/483409/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: driver-teams: establish new "driver team" concept
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-28 17:51:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/368ae395a65d15b91d49ac3db40d4085fbacd082', 'message': 'driver-teams: establish a new "driver team" concept

The OpenStack community wants to encourage collaboration between
vendors.  At the same time, we don't want to require project teams to
"own" code they are not comfortable managing by forcing all drivers to
be a part of the consuming project team's deliverables. We need to
provide a compromise that encourages vendor participation in the
community while recognizing that providing a driver for an OpenStack
project does not give any individual vendor an advantage, because all
vendors can create and deliver drivers.

Drivers are second-order objects from main projects, limited to
implementing a specific published interface. We can therefore use a
different set of requirements for "driver teams" and allow them to have
more flexibility in terms of level playing field or open
collaboration. We recognize it's a price to pay in order to make the
main projects successful. To clearly mark the difference, "driver teams"
will be listed in a separate yaml file, with a structure resembling
projects.yaml.

Co-Authored-By: Thierry Carrez <thierry@openstack.org>
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
Change-Id: I3aa10add59fc8b06cb1d3948ef484c3980282c74
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-12-12 13:05:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/2420cacd53085ee0c49566a9fdcba70919bbaf00', 'message': 'driver-teams: establish new "driver team" concept

An important function of 'OpenStack' is to provide and enable
open collaboration playgrounds, so that multiple organizations
and individual contributors can work together on a project as
equals. Drivers are a sort of exception here: they may end up
not being developed as a level-playing-field open collaboration,
but they are instrumental to the success of their consuming project.

This "grey" option is a trade-off: rather than excluding driver
teams from our community (black options) or compromising on our
principles (white options) or forcing teams to carry driver code
(red option), it clearly defines a narrow and limited case where it
benefits OpenStack to be more flexible, defines specific requirements
around it, and keeps track of which project teams follow such case.

Drivers are second-order objects from main projects, limited to
implementing a specific published interface. We can therefore use a
different set of requirements for "driver teams" and allow them to have
more flexibility in terms of level playing field or open collaboration.
We recognize it's a price to pay in order to make the main projects
successful.

However, we don't want this process to end up creating a "registry of
official drivers" or specific brand visibility that would encourage
drivers to file as separate project teams. Drivers should really be
listed in project documentation and the OpenStack Marketplace, not in
governance documents. To reduce that risk, brand names should not be
part of the team name itself. Furthermore, driver teams won't use a
specific tag or a separate YAML file (which would end up generating a
specific webpage), they will be listed together with other teams. The
YAML entry will use a "type: driver" property to allow machines to
read that the team scope is limited to drivers, without having to
parse their mission statement prose.

Co-Authored-By: Thierry Carrez <thierry@openstack.org>
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
Change-Id: I3aa10add59fc8b06cb1d3948ef484c3980282c74
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-12-12 13:22:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/d973a2974264aba749a7ff8487dd2c547a3125af', 'message': 'driver-teams: establish new "driver team" concept

An important function of 'OpenStack' is to provide and enable
open collaboration playgrounds, so that multiple organizations
and individual contributors can work together on a project as
equals. Drivers are a sort of exception here: they may end up
not being developed as a level-playing-field open collaboration,
but they are instrumental to the success of their consuming project.

This "grey" option is a trade-off: rather than excluding driver
teams from our community (black options) or compromising on our
principles (white options) or forcing teams to carry driver code
(red option), it clearly defines a narrow and limited case where it
benefits OpenStack to be more flexible, defines specific requirements
around it, and keeps track of which project teams follow such case.

Drivers are second-order objects from main projects, limited to
implementing a specific published interface. We can therefore use a
different set of requirements for "driver teams" and allow them to have
more flexibility in terms of level playing field or open collaboration.
We recognize it's a price to pay in order to make the main projects
successful.

However, we don't want this process to end up creating a "registry of
official drivers" or specific brand visibility that would encourage
drivers to file as separate project teams. Drivers should really be
listed in project documentation and the OpenStack Marketplace, not in
governance documents. To reduce that risk, brand names should not be
part of the team name itself. Furthermore, driver teams won't use a
specific tag or a separate YAML file (which would end up generating a
specific webpage), they will be listed together with other teams. The
YAML entry will use a "type: driver" property to allow machines to
read that the team scope is limited to drivers, without having to
parse their mission statement prose.

Co-Authored-By: Thierry Carrez <thierry@openstack.org>
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
Change-Id: I3aa10add59fc8b06cb1d3948ef484c3980282c74

commit_message:
driver-teams: establish new "driver team" concept

An important function of 'OpenStack' is to provide and enable
open collaboration playgrounds, so that multiple organizations
and individual contributors can work together on a project as
equals. Drivers are a sort of exception here: they may end up
not being developed as a level-playing-field open collaboration,
but they are instrumental to the success of their consuming project.

This "grey" option is a trade-off: rather than excluding driver
teams from our community (black options) or compromising on our
principles (white options) or forcing teams to carry driver code
(red option), it clearly defines a narrow and limited case where it
benefits OpenStack to be more flexible, defines specific requirements
around it, and keeps track of which project teams follow such case.

Drivers are second-order objects from main projects, limited to
implementing a specific published interface. We can therefore use a
different set of requirements for "driver teams" and allow them to have
more flexibility in terms of level playing field or open collaboration.
We recognize it's a price to pay in order to make the main projects
successful.

However, we don't want this process to end up creating a "registry of
official drivers" or specific brand visibility that would encourage
drivers to file as separate project teams. Drivers should really be
listed in project documentation and the OpenStack Marketplace, not in
governance documents. To reduce that risk, brand names should not be
part of the team name itself. Furthermore, driver teams won't use a
specific tag or a separate YAML file (which would end up generating a
specific webpage), they will be listed together with other teams. The
YAML entry will use a "type: driver" property to allow machines to
read that the team scope is limited to drivers, without having to
parse their mission statement prose.

Co-Authored-By: Thierry Carrez <thierry@openstack.org>
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
Change-Id: I3aa10add59fc8b06cb1d3948ef484c3980282c74
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/29/403829/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ====================================================== Requirements for new OpenStack Driver team applications ====================================================== Driver Teams in OpenStack can be created as-needed and grow organically. By becoming an official OpenStack team, they place themselves under the authority of the OpenStack Technical Committee. In return, their contributors get to vote in the Technical Committee election. When considering new driver teams for addition, the TC will check several criteria: * Team Scope * The team works on drivers or plug-ins that exploit existing plug-in points in OpenStack projects * The proposed deliverables do not extend the REST APIs of the services consuming them * Community Engagement * The team proactively engaged with the parent project(s) to check for opportunities of being developed in-tree before being set up as a separate team * The team interacts with all projects that consume their deliverables by regularly participating to the project team meetings on IRC and engaging with the project on the openstack-dev mailing-list as needed to ensure seamless collaboration * The team provides liaisons that serve as contacts for the work of cross-project teams in OpenStack, where needed * The team should have one or more active contributors * The team meets any policies that the TC requires all deliverables to meet. For instance, the :doc:`project-testing-interface` * Openness * The proposed deliverables meet the :doc:`licensing` * The leadership is chosen by the contributors to the team * The team uses public code reviews on the OpenStack infrastructure * The team has core reviewers and adopts a test-driven gate in the OpenStack infrastructure for changes In order to do an evaluation against this criteria, the TC expects the team to be set up and have some history to evaluate. A few weeks of operating and following these team requirements is a rough guideline for how long to wait before applying to be approved by the TC. Once a driver team has joined OpenStack, it may create additional source code repositories as needed at the discretion of its Team Lead without prior approval from the TC as long as the additional source code repositories fall within the scope of the approved project mission statement.

commit_message:
Cleanup the orchestration client init and attr

Clients.py inits the orchestration client and defines and attribute
in the client manager for it. The only known consumers of attribute
are Tempest itself in the cleanup service and Murano.

I proposed a patch to Murano: Ic6fef4b4f260d13efd7b035bc012369f0da55602

The aim is to make clients stable for plugins, and I don't want the
Heat client to be in the stable interface since it's not something
that we will be supporting on Tempest side: all the Heat config
values are deprecated and will be removed during Queens.

Depends-on: Ic6fef4b4f260d13efd7b035bc012369f0da55602
Change-Id: I9f4703296a44e741cab8db6b52ba410b7dd3bed6

commit_message:
Add list capability

Adds ability to list secrets, and adds initial filtering ability. Can
filter by secret_type.

Depends-On: I583f27f91cb3c6bdb23438dff6b539407b4005ed
Depends-On: I99cd72724e11bab362bcaaeb773f33b2abfe815c
Change-Id: I245d5846aa8d3b9586bea6dc4e0b24db86c911c9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/castellan refs/changes/19/418019/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def cleanUp(self): super(MockKeyManagerTestCase, self).cleanUp() self.key_mgr.keys = {} def test_list_null_context(self): self.assertRaises(exception.Forbidden, self.key_mgr.list, None) def test_list_keys(self): key1 = sym_key.SymmetricKey('AES', 64 * 8, bytes(b'0' * 64)) key1_id = self.key_mgr.store(self.context, key1) key2 = sym_key.SymmetricKey('AES', 32 * 8, bytes(b'0' * 32)) key2_id = self.key_mgr.store(self.context, key2) keys = self.key_mgr.list(self.context) self.assertEqual(2, len(keys)) self.assertTrue(key1_id in keys) self.assertTrue(key2_id in keys)

commit_message:
Describe the action_target handling for external actions

Change-Id: I30e83c175b66871f9a8d728d0d79d8907a612611
Implements: blueprint support-external-actions
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/vitrage-specs refs/changes/54/484654/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Calculate the action_target --------------------------- Every "regular" action (raise_alarm, set_state, add_causal_relationship) has an action_target block. The action_target has no meaning for the external actions, since they are managed by an external engine that does not have a "target" terminology. The problem is that the action_target is essential for the subgraph-matching calculations, in order to calculate the connected components. The proposed solution ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ For external actions, we will automatically calculate an action target. The target will be selected arbitrarily from the set of possible targets. In complex conditions that involve {and, or, not} finding the target might not be trivial. Some more-complex conditions will not be supported for external actions, due to this reason. The calculation method: * And condition - any vertex that is part of the condition can be a target * Not condition - no vertex that is part of the condition can be a target * Or condition - the target should be a vertex that appears in any "positive" part of the Or condition Examples: ~~~~~~~~~ +----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------+ | Condition | Possible targets| +----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------+ | a_in_error_status | a | +----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------+ | a_contains_b | a, b | +----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------+ | a_contains_b or a_contains_c | a | +----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------+ | a_contains_b or a_contains_c or a_contains_d | a | +----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------+ | a_in_error_status or a_contains_c or a_contains_d | a | +----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------+ | a_contains_b or a_contains_c or b_contains_d | / | +----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------+ | a_contains_b and a_contains_c | a, b, c | +----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------+ | a_contains_b and a_contains_c and a_contains_d | a, b, c, d | +----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------+ | a_contains_b or (a_contains_c and a_contains_d) | a | +----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------+ | a_contains_b or (a_contains_c and b_contains_d) | a,b | +----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------+ | not a_contains_b | / | +----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------+ | not a_in_error_status | / | +----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------+ | a_contains_b or not a_contains_c | / | +----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------+ | a_contains_b or (a_contains_c and not a_contains_d) | a | +----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------+ | a_contains_b or (not a_contains_c and not a_contains_d) | / | +----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------+ Alternatives to calculating the action_target --------------------------------------------- We can decide that an external action requires an action_target like all other actions. This will simplify the implementation, but is logically wrong. The action_target will serve as a "helper entity" for the subgraph-matching, and it should not be the end user's role to help fixing implementation issues. As far as the external engine is concerned, the action_target has no meaning.

commit_message:
Adding chart for docker registry and serving master images

Docker registry will be running as a pod, if configured, it will load
tarball with images and start serviceg then inside of a kubernetes cluster.

Change-Id: I9b0df3c27148b22b204403a38e8b49495e31e03f

commit_message:
Crushmap Update Action

This action takes a json definition of a crushmap and
applies it.

Change-Id: Icaabc89016be22aa16d2f813a746842fd30fd989
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-ceph-mon refs/changes/54/388854/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: crushmap-update: description: | Apply a json crushmap definition. This will throw away the existing ceph crushmap and apply the new definition. Use with extreme caution. WARNING - This function is extremely dangerous if misused. It can very easily break your cluster in unexpected ways. params: map: type: string description: The json crushmap blob required: [map] additionalProperties: false

commit_message:
Enable IPv6 in manila(allow access)

Please read spec for design detail [1].

Add support to validate IPv6 based addresses
in allow access API when access type is IP.

[1] f7202a6cfe32a057f752a4e393f848f8a0211c36

APIImpact
DocImpact

Change-Id: Ica242007e77a7e21b2151e5fc32401b501d961b2
Partial-Implements: blueprint support-ipv6-access
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/21/312321/21 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: elif req.api_version_request < api_version.APIVersionRequest("2.16"): else: return self._allow_access(req, id, body, enable_ceph=True, enable_ipv6=True)

commit_message:
Remove the user-guide

The useful content in the user guide is all being moved to
project-specific docsets. We can remove the guide here, and replace it
with a /user/ landing page that provides links to all of the known user
guides for services and clients.

Change-Id: I7005b4288b94e755f406fd6a8e3273265b643042
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Added examples to create event based alarm

- Aodh event based alarm using single and multiple traits
- New sub-section in 'Debug alarm'
- Correct path to aodh.conf.sample file
- Seperated example sections into
  - Threshold based alarm
  - Composite alarm
  - Event based alarm

Change-Id: I0b025a7401ad7feaf05f7e31e77cd3f92c9761a0
Signed-off-by: Sachin Patil <psachin@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/aodh refs/changes/18/484118/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: To enable this functionality, config the Ceilometer to be able to publish events to the queue the aodh-listener service listen on. The *event_alarm_topic* config option of Aodh identify which messaging topic the aodh-listener on, the default value is "alarm.all". In Ceilometer side, a publisher of notifier type need to be configured in the event pipeline config file(``event_pipeline.yaml`` as default), the notifier should be with a messaging topic same as the *event_alarm_topic* option defined. For an example::

In Ceilometer side, a publisher of notifier type need to be configured in the event pipeline config file(event_pipeline.yaml as default), the notifier should be with a messaging topic same as the *event_alarm_topic* option defined. commit_message:
remove automatic python3 support detection

Switch from implicitly installing services under python3 when they claim
support to always requiring an explicit setting for
ENABLED_PYTHON3_PACKAGES. This gives projects more control over the test
jobs where their dependencies may claim python3 support that is
incomplete or unstable.

Change-Id: I6dbc8e531fde799fc3bfdd4edfc55e1c0f81cb26
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/08/439108/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Look for the package being installed in the list of # packages that should be installed under Python 3, # and use pip3 if necessary. echo "Defaulting to using $PYTHON2_VERSION version to install $package"
deleted_lines: # Determine the python versions supported by a package function get_python_versions_for_package { local name=$1 cd $name && python setup.py --classifiers \ | grep 'Language' | cut -f5 -d: | grep '\.' | tr '\n' ' ' } # Check for python3 classifier in local directory function check_python3_support_for_package_local { local name=$1 cd $name set +e classifier=$(python setup.py --classifiers \ | grep 'Programming Language :: Python :: 3$') set -e echo $classifier } # Check for python3 classifier on pypi function check_python3_support_for_package_remote { local name=$1 set +e classifier=$(curl -s -L "https://pypi.python.org/pypi/$name/json" \ | grep '"Programming Language :: Python :: 3"') set -e echo $classifier } # Look at the package classifiers to find the python # versions supported, and if we find the version of # python3 we've been told to use, use that instead of the # default pip local python_versions # Special case some services that have experimental # support for python3 in progress, but don't claim support # in their classifier elif [[ -d "$package_dir" ]]; then python_versions=$(get_python_versions_for_package $package_dir) if [[ $python_versions =~ $PYTHON3_VERSION ]]; then echo "Automatically using $PYTHON3_VERSION version to install $package_dir based on classifiers" sudo_pip="$sudo_pip LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8" cmd_pip=$(get_pip_command $PYTHON3_VERSION) else # The package may not have yet advertised python3.5 # support so check for just python3 classifier and log # a warning. python3_classifier=$(check_python3_support_for_package_local $package_dir) if [[ ! -z "$python3_classifier" ]]; then echo "Automatically using $PYTHON3_VERSION version to install $package_dir based on local package settings" sudo_pip="$sudo_pip LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8" cmd_pip=$(get_pip_command $PYTHON3_VERSION) fi fi # Check pypi as we don't have the package on disk package=$(echo $package_dir | grep -o '^[.a-zA-Z0-9_-]*') python3_classifier=$(check_python3_support_for_package_remote $package) if [[ ! -z "$python3_classifier" ]]; then echo "Automatically using $PYTHON3_VERSION version to install $package based on remote package settings" sudo_pip="$sudo_pip LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8" cmd_pip=$(get_pip_command $PYTHON3_VERSION) fi

commit_message:
Remove ceilometer-api and ceilometer-collector services

* remove ceilometer-api and ceilometer-collector service
* use ceilometer-notification to publish message to proper backend
* remove useless ceilometer_database_type and ceilometer_event_type
  variables
* sync event_definitions.yaml, event_pipeline.yaml and pipeline.yaml
  file with upstream

Change-Id: Ib39053cb5f70bd11ee61d3f26d5b28accecd7190

commit_message:
driver-teams: add a resolution allowing teams based on vendor-specific drivers

The OpenStack community wants to encourage collaboration between
vendors.  At the same time, we don't want to require project teams to
"own" code they are not comfortable managing by forcing all drivers to
be a part of the consuming project team's deliverables. We need to
provide a compromise that encourages vendor participation in the
community while recognizing that providing a driver for an OpenStack
project does not give any individual vendor an advantage, because all
vendors can create and deliver drivers.

Co-Authored-By: Thierry Carrez <thierry@openstack.org>
Change-Id: I91c72fb69e99bb2e33ba6be51641bd0ca0cbf68e
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/26/403826/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ========================================================= 2016-11-28 Allow Teams Based on Vendor-specific Drivers ========================================================= The OpenStack community wants to encourage collaboration by emphasizing contributions to projects that abstract differences between vendor-specific products, while still empowering vendors to integrate their products with OpenStack through drivers that can be consumed by the abstraction layers. We strongly prefer that drivers are included in the consuming projects and managed by the same contributors in a collaborative fashion, whether by including drivers "in tree" or by placing them in separate repositories owned by the same team. However, we don't want to require project teams to "own" code they are not comfortable managing by forcing all drivers to be a part of the consuming project team's deliverables. Some teams for projects that use drivers may not want to manage some or all of the drivers that can be consumed by their project because they have little insight into testing or debugging the code, or do not have the resources needed to manage centrally a large number of separate drivers. Vendors are of course free to produce drivers to integrate with OpenStack completely outside of the community, but because the community values having the drivers as well as the more general support of vendor companies, we want to encourage a higher level of engagement by welcoming vendor-specific teams to be a part of our community governance. Our :doc:`../reference/new-projects-requirements` list includes a statement about establishing a "level and open collaboration playing field" The project shall provide a level and open collaboration playing field for all contributors. The project shall not benefit a single vendor, or a single vendors product offerings; nor advantage contributors from a single vendor organization due to access to source code, hardware, resources or other proprietary technology available only to those contributors. By encouraging vendors to manage the implementation of their drivers in the open and on community infrastructure, we ensure this level playing field. Although a given driver may only be useful in conjunction with equipment or software from a single vendor, it may benefit many of our users who have the required equipment or software. Having the team producing the driver as part of our community makes it easier for those users to engage with them, and for the driver team to engage with other teams throughout the community. Moving drivers out of the consuming projects raises the question of who is responsible for the resulting code, the consuming project team or the driver team. The reason for documenting all of our teams and their repositories is to ensure that we communicate the ownership clearly. By granting official status to the driver team, we can make it easier for users of the driver to direct queries and bugs to the right audience and establish a clear demarcation of the responsibilities of the different teams. The driver team would be "official", but the driver code would not necessarily be "supported" by the consuming project team. Although this governance change adds a new path to create official teams, we do not want to break up existing teams. We strongly prefer that drivers are included in the consuming projects and managed by the same contributors in a collaborative fashion. The option to have an official team focused on a vendor-specific driver should be used as a last resort, when in-project hosting for the driver is not working.

commit_message:
Add choices field to config definition

When generating cloudkitty.conf.sample with `oslo-config-generator`, this
will provide "Allowed values" information in configurations, so people
needn't check the code base to get the values.

Change-Id: I57bcbd1fbe9588760f25ff865d364473a7779323

commit_message:
Allow override of the auth_url used for federation

Today, when enabling federation use in Horizon, the websso_url
that is derived from the AVAILABLE_REGIONS and OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_URL
parameters doesn't work well when the keystone server is behind
haproxy and horizon has no access to the public network.

This patch adds an override as part of another variable called
FEDERATION_AUTH_URL. Thus Horizon will redirect properly when HAProxy
is in use and authenticate normally when using non-federate logins.

Change-Id: I91d461cd65f3eaf81ccf4bd933da3a01f18a1289

commit_message:
Drop MANIFEST.in - it's not needed by pbr

django_openstack_auth already uses PBR:-
setuptools.setup(
	setup_requires=['pbr>=1.8'],
	pbr=True)

This patch removes `MANIFEST.in` file as pbr generates a
sensible manifest from git files and some standard files
and it removes the need for an explicit `MANIFEST.in` file.

Change-Id: Id1a392a5dd9bcbf280e912edd935b6be926017ef

commit_message:
Correct handling of domain policy checks

The policy check code generates two sets of credentials, one relating to
a project scoped token if available, and one to a domain scoped token,
if available. There was some attempts to make the two look identical
which defaulted domain_id to user_domain_id, with the effect that policy
checks requiring domain-scope could accidentally pass.

This patch removes the user_domain_id->domain_id assignment such that if
domain_id is set, it indicates that the user is scoped to a domain.
Similarly, a policy check requiring a domain_id will not pass unless
domain credentials are present. It is still not possible to assert that
a user is both a project AND domain admin, but I don't think this is
possible in keystone either.

Change-Id: I62a15942dfa5a9be3e4e6ea846309617c374c4b1
Closes-Bug: #1616669

added_lines: # Some additional domain fields for key, src_key in [('user_id', 'id'), ('domain_id', 'domain_id'), ('project_id', 'project_id'), ('project_name', 'project_name'), ('user.domain_id', 'user_domain_id'), ('user.domain_name', 'user_domain_name'), ('project.domain_id', 'project_domain_id'), ('project.domain_name', 'project_domain_name')]: if target.get(key) is None: target[key] = getattr(user, src_key) # Special case for tenant_id # Previously group.domain_id was set to user_domain_id but # I don't think we have access to a valid value for it. # TODO(sjmc7) The separation here means that rules like # "am a project admin and am a domain admin" are impossible # Do NOT include domain_id here because if the user's authenticated to # a domain _domain_to_credentials will be used instead user._domain_credentials['domain_name'] = domain_user.domain_name

subject: Rename 'AVAILABLE_REGIONS' to 'KEYSTONE_ENDPOINTS'
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-17 14:28:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/django_openstack_auth/commit/a54f5633e6c59706bb44ca0dcbf12f191c44d10d', 'message': "Prepare for 'AVAILABLE_REGIONS' renaming

The idea is not only rename 'AVAILABLE_REGIONS' ->
'KEYSTONE_ENDPOINTS', but also change all in-code `region` mentions to
`endpoint` mentions (and in session variable names as well). That will
prevent any further confusion. But in order to keep Horizon (using old
session variable names) working once the new openstack_auth (which
uses new variable names) is released, we need to keep the knowledge
about variable names in one place. And this place is openstack_auth
variable getters.

P.S. Here we only touch regions as keystone endpoints and not service
regions (which as of now are confused with each other).

need to keep the knowledge about variable names in one place. And this
place is openstack_auth variable getters.

P.S. Here we only touch regions as keystone endpoints and not service
regions (which as of now are confused with each other).

Change-Id: If9090d729e52317fffe0045f39a7f17d9b578372
Related-Bug: #1494251

commit_message:
Rename 'AVAILABLE_REGIONS' to 'KEYSTONE_ENDPOINTS'

The idea is not only rename 'AVAILABLE_REGIONS' ->
'KEYSTONE_ENDPOINTS', but also change all in-code `region` mentions to
`endpoint` mentions (and in session variable names as well). That will
prevent any further confusion. The legacy 'AVAILABLE_REGIONS' name
still could be used for indefinite (as of now) time, but will cause a
deprecation warning. Provide a separate function for getting the
actual value and make it responsible for the deprecation warning.

Also introduce some redundancy knowledge (marked with # FIXME comment)
to keep old Horizon backwards compatible with new release of
django-openstack-auth. All these lines could be safely removed once a
dependent Horizon commit is merged (and stable branches should be
capped to not use django-openstack-auth with backwards compatibility
lines removed).

P.S. Here we only touch regions as keystone endpoints and not service
regions (which as of now are confused with each other).

Needed-By: I77bf8f71ddcc3910666c7addb74494291699683f
Change-Id: If9090d729e52317fffe0045f39a7f17d9b578372
Partial-Bug: #1494251
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/django_openstack_auth refs/changes/56/224756/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_current_endpoint_url(request): return request.session.get('region_endpoint', None) def get_current_endpoint_name(request): return request.session.get('region_name', None)

commit_message:
Add 'Remember me' checkbox to the login form.

This option allows users to log in for longer sessions
(default: 1 day) when using a trusted device.  It relies
on the new config setting 'SESSION_SHORT_TIMEOUT' which is
introduced in a separate patch.

Change-Id: I30e1f16ff2c1d76f2615cbcf792e1d7b830b9668
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/django_openstack_auth refs/changes/91/390891/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if 'extended_session' in kwargs and kwargs['extended_session']: timeout = getattr(settings, "SESSION_TIMEOUT", 86400) else: timeout = getattr(settings, "SESSION_SHORT_TIMEOUT", 3600)

commit_message:
Add missing pip install to quickstart guide

When following the quickstart guide I noticed that
the evaluation workflow doesn't mention installing
kolla, which causes problems later on when
kolla-build is needed.

Change-Id: I9cd336c636b9c026ea82938084aa3d34a85e33f1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/85/449685/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Install kolla, kolla-ansible, and their dependencies using pip. pip install kolla kolla-ansible
deleted_lines: Install kolla-ansible and its dependencies using pip. pip install kolla-ansible

openstack-infra.

commit_message:
Bump Ansible version to include include_role fix

include_role has issues with dependencies, in that a conditional applied
to an unrelated dependency can be applied to the "include_role:".

Ansible dependency fix backport SHA: 4d585c9035a2e07c8040727e62c0699bb1e87a22

Additionally, SHA bump the ceph_client role to fix Ceph builds for
CentOS7 now that the Ansible version has been bumped.

Change-Id: I8e1d87dc45b25d8146450545ad1ec8e4b107f104

commit_message:
use domainListGetStats to get cputime

info() from domain returns cputime value rounded to tenth of a
second. we should just use domainListGetStats to get full nanosecond
detail.

Related-bug: #1677159
Related-bug: #1421584
Change-Id: I8d3f5fa8c683a0cbd9cca7072fa4862b8c00c224
(cherry picked from commit fb6cd01753672f7bd70ca29f4c1de6f3d150ba10)

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary ceph mon pdb

Ceph mon has been changed from a statefulset to a daemonset,
so the PodDisruptionBudget is no longer needed.

Change-Id: I86d46ed2e6377177eff9251d5e4f3bb433eaf250

commit_message:
nova-manage cell_v2 map_cell0 exit 0

This command used to always return 1 because it was returning a data
structure used by another CLI function.  Now it exits 0 if the cell0
mapping was created succesfully or was already there.

Closes-Bug: #1656017
Change-Id: Ie66de8425bb8f65dc9eab9d0da809e94f6d72b1b

commit_message:
Allow promotion featureset024 job to report its status

After transition updates job was renamed to featureset024 and
it should be included in promotion job to report its status.

Change-Id: I09861cc593602696184fe4e09cb00b6c3f095884

commit_message:
Adding DontCache for mirrorlist.centos.org

Dont cache mirrorlist.centos.org to prevent hitting:
- Could not retrieve mirrorlist * -14: HTTP Error 503 - Service Unavailable

commit_message:
Make volume_qos_client use **kwargs

As we discussed on
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-July/068864.html
All http POST/PUT methods need to contain **kwargs as their arguments.
This patch makes volume_qos_client use **kwargs.

Partially implements blueprint consistent-service-method-names

Change-Id: I0dfe120ebe3fdc83d48c2ac7e58cf925a94bcfc1

commit_message:
Reduce ansible bootstrap packages

The current distro package install set is quite
broad, especially for xenial. This reduces the
set.

The get pip process is also simplified and the
virtualenv creation is normalised across python
versions.

The virtualenv creation process is also normalised
across distributions now that localhost tasks now
specify the host python executable instead of the
runtime ansible python venv.

Change-Id: I27a41d583d0ea9f7499f51e69686d1b865958e2e

commit_message:
Remove missing swift configuration files

The Mitaka version of the swift configuration files have been removed
from the swift repo because Mitaka is end of life. This prevents the
base disk from building.

We could update the URLs to Ocata, but then our Ocata release would stop
working as soon as Ocata is EOL just because these files will be removed
as well. That is entirely unnecessary because right now, swift is
unsupported and the configuration files are not needed. For that reason,
just remove the configuration files until we need them.

Change-Id: I0739feec073d76cc62ade92d21b4e6bb8d1694f3
(cherry picked from commit bb26a284be8a9115fac798d830efa79f11511fe8)

commit_message:
Final releases of oslo for Pike

This commit bump each library's minor version due to the final release
for Pike.

Note: this commit doesn't include releases for pylockfile and tooz

Change-Id: I8bea7bf3bea2f048a13ed1e714f87835dfbcb265

API (microversion 1.7)

added_lines: def adopt(self, session, preview=False, **params): """Adopt a node for management. :param session: A session object used for sending request. :param preview: A boolean indicating whether the adoption is a preview. A "preview" does not create the node object. :param dict params: A dict providing the details of a node to be adopted. """ path = "adopt-preview" if preview else "adopt" url = utils.urljoin(self.base_path, path) resp = session.post(url, endpoint_filter=self.service, json=params) if preview: return resp.json() self._translate_response(resp) return self

- Could not retrieve mirrorlist * -14: HTTP Error 503 - Service Unavailable

commit_message:
Update tox_install.sh to allow fetching several projects.

Update tox_install.sh/tox_install_project.sh to ones used in
networking-odl. Needed for [1], which adds dependency on
networking-sfc tree

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/406597

Change-Id: I842d23f09930ed4d7c31e5e60af23ec20850f45c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/dragonflow refs/changes/87/484187/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env bash # Many of neutron's repos suffer from the problem of depending on neutron, # but it not existing on pypi. # This wrapper for tox's package installer will use # the local tree in home directory if exists, # else the existing package if it exists, # else use zuul-cloner if that program exists, # else grab it from project master via https://git.openstack.org/openstack, # That last case should only happen with devs running unit tests locally. # From the tox.ini config page: # install_command=ARGV # default: # pip install {opts} {packages} PROJ=$1 MOD=$2 shift 2 ZUUL_CLONER=/usr/zuul-env/bin/zuul-cloner proj_installed=$(echo "import ${MOD}" | python 2>/dev/null ; echo $?) BRANCH_NAME=master set -e set -x CONSTRAINTS_FILE=$1 shift install_cmd="pip install" if [ $CONSTRAINTS_FILE != "unconstrained" ]; then install_cmd="$install_cmd -c$CONSTRAINTS_FILE" fi if [ $proj_installed -eq 0 ]; then echo "ALREADY INSTALLED" > /tmp/tox_install-${PROJ}.txt location=$(python -c "import ${MOD}; print(${MOD}.__file__)") echo "ALREADY INSTALLED at $location" echo "${PROJ} already installed; using existing package" elif [ -x "$ZUUL_CLONER" ]; then echo "ZUUL CLONER" > /tmp/tox_install-${PROJ}.txt # Make this relative to current working directory so that # git clean can remove it. We cannot remove the directory directly # since it is referenced after $install_cmd -e. mkdir -p .tmp PROJECT_DIR=$(/bin/mktemp -d -p $(pwd)/.tmp) pushd $PROJECT_DIR $ZUUL_CLONER --cache-dir \ /opt/git \ --branch ${BRANCH_NAME} \ git://git.openstack.org \ openstack/${PROJ} cd openstack/${PROJ} $install_cmd -e . popd else echo "PIP HARDCODE" > /tmp/tox_install-${PROJ}.txt $install_cmd -U -egit+https://git.openstack.org/openstack/${PROJ}@${BRANCH_NAME}#egg=${PROJ} fi

added_lines: "POT-Creation-Date: 2017-07-17 04:26+0000\n""PO-Revision-Date: 2017-07-17 01:32+0000\n""API endpoints are now displayed on the OpenStack RC File panel so they can " "be organically discovered by an end-user." msgstr "" "Endpoints de API são agora mostrados no painel Arquivo RC do OpenStack de " "modo que eles possam ser organicamente descobertos pelo usuário final." msgid ""msgid "Better cross-browser support (Safari and IE particularly)." msgstr "Melhor suporte para navegadores (Safari e IE particularmente)." msgid "Better validation of what actions are permitted when." msgstr "Melhor validação de quais ações são permitidas e quando." msgid "DataTables now support a summation row at the bottom of the table." msgstr "DataTables agora suporta uma linha de somatório no final da tabela." msgid "Deleting large numbers of resources simultaneously" msgstr "Exclusão de um grande número de recursos simultaneamente" msgid "Fewer API calls to OpenStack endpoints (improves performance)." msgstr "Menos chamadas de API aos endpoints OpenStack (melhora o desempenho)." msgid "Floating IPs and Quantum" msgstr "IPs Flutuantes e Quantum" msgid "Grizzly Series Release Notes" msgstr "Notas de Versão da Série Grizzly" "Images can now be added to Glance by providing a URL for Glance to download " "the image data from." msgstr "" "Imagens agora podem ser adicionadas ao Glance através do fornecimento de uma " "URL de onde o Glance possa obter a mesma." msgid ""msgid "Improved error handling and error messages." msgstr "Tratamento de erros e mensagens de erro melhorados." "In terms of APIs provided for extending Horizon, there are a handful of " "backwards-incompatible changes that were made:" msgstr "" "Em termos de APIs fornecidas para extender o Horizon, há um punhado de " "mudanças retroativamente incompatíveis que foram feitas:" msgid """Most of the documentation has been reorganised and updated, or rewritten " "entirely, with the aim of promoting discoverability and ensuring all content " "is relevant and up to date." msgstr "" "A maior parte da documentação foi reorganizada e atualizada, ou reescrita " "completamente, com o objetivo de promover a descoberta e garantir que todo o " "conteúdo seja relevante e atualizado" msgid ""msgid "Pagination" msgstr "Paginação" msgid "Quotas are now displayed dynamically throughout the Project dashboard." msgstr "Quotas agora são mostradas dinamicamente através do dashboard Projeto." msgid "Some of the general areas of improvement include:" msgstr "Algumas das áreas gerais de melhorias incluem:" "The ``can_haz`` and ``can_haz_list`` template filters have been renamed to " "``has_permissions`` and ``has_permissions_on_list`` respectively." msgstr "" "Os modelos de filtros ``can_haz`` e ``can_haz_list`` foram renomeados para " "``has_permissions`` e ``has_permissions_on_list`` respectivamente." msgid ""

commit_message:
Ensure yum cache is ready before update

To workaround yum bug with libnss we need to make yum cache
before running update. In fact we should have done this
regardless of the bug.

Change-Id: I5b2355fb8abe3c8d4b9ce9c62b9ffdba8c1e8d9d
Resolves: rhbz#1458841
Closes-Bug: #1703830

commit_message:
api-ref: mention disk size limitations in resize flavor

In the resize API reference, mention that the specified flavor
must have a disk size greater than or equal to the current
instance flavor. This is something that doesn't get checked
in the API so it results in a failure on the compute service
which is not obvious to the API user since the instance goes
back into state 'ACTIVE'.

Change-Id: I33fc92ffa346b908a8e4f95da16a68040cfc678e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/76/484176/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: The flavor ID for resizing the server. The size of the disk in the flavor being resized to must be greater than or equal to the size of the disk in the current flavor.
deleted_lines: The flavor ID for resizing the server.

commit_message:
Expanded the best practices subsection in devdocs

As a part of reorganisation of developer docs, removed the
best practices documentation and made the subsections in it
as overall sections. More renaming and reorganisation will
be addressed in the following patches.

Change-Id: I21bf8fe3855fd1d441ec3dba342babc90516714d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/41/476541/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. Copyright 2011-2012 OpenStack Foundation All Rights Reserved. Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. Caching Layer ============= The caching layer is designed to be applied to any ``manager`` object within Keystone via the use of the ``on_arguments`` decorator provided in the ``keystone.common.cache`` module. This decorator leverages `dogpile.cache`_ caching system to provide a flexible caching backend. It is recommended that each of the managers have an independent toggle within the config file to enable caching. The easiest method to utilize the toggle within the configuration file is to define a ``caching`` boolean option within that manager's configuration section (e.g. ``identity``). Once that option is defined you can pass function to the ``on_arguments`` decorator with the named argument ``should_cache_fn``. In the ``keystone.common.cache`` module, there is a function called ``should_cache_fn``, which will provide a reference, to a function, that will consult the global cache ``enabled`` option as well as the specific manager's caching enable toggle. .. NOTE:: If a section-specific boolean option is not defined in the config section specified when calling ``should_cache_fn``, the returned function reference will default to enabling caching for that ``manager``. Example use of cache and ``should_cache_fn`` (in this example, ``token`` is the manager): .. code-block:: python from keystone.common import cache SHOULD_CACHE = cache.should_cache_fn('token') @cache.on_arguments(should_cache_fn=SHOULD_CACHE) def cacheable_function(arg1, arg2, arg3): ... return some_value With the above example, each call to the ``cacheable_function`` would check to see if the arguments passed to it matched a currently valid cached item. If the return value was cached, the caching layer would return the cached value; if the return value was not cached, the caching layer would call the function, pass the value to the ``SHOULD_CACHE`` function reference, which would then determine if caching was globally enabled and enabled for the ``token`` manager. If either caching toggle is disabled, the value is returned but not cached. It is recommended that each of the managers have an independent configurable time-to-live (TTL). If a configurable TTL has been defined for the manager configuration section, it is possible to pass it to the ``cache.on_arguments`` decorator with the named-argument ``expiration_time``. For consistency, it is recommended that this option be called ``cache_time`` and default to ``None``. If the ``expiration_time`` argument passed to the decorator is set to ``None``, the expiration time will be set to the global default (``expiration_time`` option in the ``[cache]`` configuration section. Example of using a section specific ``cache_time`` (in this example, ``identity`` is the manager): .. code-block:: python from keystone.common import cache SHOULD_CACHE = cache.should_cache_fn('identity') @cache.on_arguments(should_cache_fn=SHOULD_CACHE, expiration_time=CONF.identity.cache_time) def cachable_function(arg1, arg2, arg3): ... return some_value For cache invalidation, the ``on_arguments`` decorator will add an ``invalidate`` method (attribute) to your decorated function. To invalidate the cache, you pass the same arguments to the ``invalidate`` method as you would the normal function. Example (using the above cacheable_function): .. code-block:: python def invalidate_cache(arg1, arg2, arg3): cacheable_function.invalidate(arg1, arg2, arg3) .. WARNING:: The ``on_arguments`` decorator does not accept keyword-arguments/named arguments. An exception will be raised if keyword arguments are passed to a caching-decorated function. .. NOTE:: In all cases methods work the same as functions except if you are attempting to invalidate the cache on a decorated bound-method, you need to pass ``self`` to the ``invalidate`` method as the first argument before the arguments. .. _`dogpile.cache`: http://dogpilecache.readthedocs.org/ dogpile.cache based MongoDB (NoSQL) backend ------------------------------------------- The ``dogpile.cache`` based MongoDB backend implementation allows for various MongoDB configurations, e.g., standalone, a replica set, sharded replicas, with or without SSL, use of TTL type collections, etc. Example of typical configuration for MongoDB backend: .. code-block:: python from dogpile.cache import region arguments = { 'db_hosts': 'localhost:27017', 'db_name': 'ks_cache', 'cache_collection': 'cache', 'username': 'test_user', 'password': 'test_password', # optional arguments 'son_manipulator': 'my_son_manipulator_impl' } region.make_region().configure('keystone.cache.mongo', arguments=arguments) The optional `son_manipulator` is used to manipulate custom data type while its saved in or retrieved from MongoDB. If the dogpile cached values contain built-in data types and no custom classes, then the provided implementation class is sufficient. For further details, refer http://api.mongodb.org/python/current/examples/custom_type.html#automatic-encoding-and-decoding Similar to other backends, this backend can be added via Keystone configuration in ``keystone.conf``:: [cache] # Global cache functionality toggle. enabled = True # Referring to specific cache backend backend = keystone.cache.mongo # Backend specific configuration arguments backend_argument = db_hosts:localhost:27017 backend_argument = db_name:ks_cache backend_argument = cache_collection:cache backend_argument = username:test_user backend_argument = password:test_password This backend is registered in ``keystone.common.cache.core`` module. So, its usage is similar to other dogpile caching backends as it implements the same dogpile APIs.

Merged the caching subsections in admin docs

Currently there are two subsections named caching layer in
the admin docs. This commit merges the information in the
two and removes the duplicate docs.

commit_message:
Disable mod-wsgi deployment of keystone

Changes rollbacks monasca-api devstack back to
using uwsgi (default) keystone deployed.
All components (api, agent, ui and client) are
capable of working with keystone deployed in such way.

Note:
  This is only for python

Depends-On: I579f6bcd5975a32af2a255be41c9b6c4043fa1dc
Depends-On: Ifee5b88ccb632222310aafb1081ecb9c9d085150
Depends-On: I01d0f3d9814376f9358feb23494e1ca5231aedac
Depends-On: I1712a24739438e2d8331a495f18f357749a633c5
Depende-On: I35f5943ae1eadb10dc416179c575cdad62753b69
Change-Id: Ic307c065e717d4682f1f6d42e3d48b5ea113cb5f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-api refs/changes/16/479216/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Remove deprecated cfg in notification and add format-v6 test

- Remove 'format' cfg in nova and neutron notification
- Modify related tests with 'format' cfg
- Add formatv6 test-case for nova
- Add releasenotes for these change.

Change-Id: I5bcc7c59f23d8d66252ca6809fc78803c0bbdab7

commit_message:
Remove kwargs from adapter.get_endpoint_data

get_endpoint_data on an adapater is intended to return the endpoint_data
for the endpoint the adapter is mounted to, so passing in additional
kwargs doesn't make any sense. What's more, the interaction between the
existing values and the passed in values is hard to reason about.

Update the docs on using get_endpoint_data to highlight this.

Change-Id: I851c615407bc3e22af4350a4facf8488fa9c7945
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystoneauth refs/changes/44/482744/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: the endpoint found for a given service: ``get_endpoint_data``. On the :class:`keystoneauth1.session.Session` it takes the same arguments as `endpoint_filter`. On the :class:`keystoneauth1.adapter.Adapter` it does not take arguments, as it returns the information for the Endpoint the Adapter is mounted on. ``get_endpoint_data`` returns an :class:`keystoneauth1.discovery.EndpointData` object. This object can be used to find information about the Endpoint, including which major `api_version` was found, or which `interface` in case of ranges, lists of input values or ``latest`` version. It can also be used to determine the `min_microversion` and `max_microversion` supported by the API. If an API does not support microversions, the values for both will be ``None``.process, so calling it should incur no undue expense. By default it will make at least one version discovery call so that it can fetch microversion metadata. If the user knows a service does not support microversions and is merely curious as to which major version was discovered, `discover_versions` can be set to `False` to prevent fetching microversion metadata.
deleted_lines: the endpoint found for a given service: ``get_endpoint_data``. It takes the same arguments as the `Adapter` constructor and `endpoint_filter`, and returns a :class:`keystoneauth1.discovery.EndpointData` object. This object can be used to determine which major `api_version` was found, or which `interface` in case of ranges, lists of input values or ``latest`` version. It can also be used to determine the `min_microversion` and `max_microversion` supported by the API. If an API does not support microversions, the values will be ``None``.process, so calling it should incur no undue expense. It will make at least one version discovery call so that it can fetch microversion metadata. If the user knows a service does not support microversions and is merely curious as to which major version was discovered, `discover_versions` can be set to `False` to prevent fetching microversion metadata.

commit_message:
Remove deprecated_since for interface and fix text

Version number for keystoneauth is still being debated. Remove this
as it's not strictly necessary anyway. The deprecation explanation is
also very clunky. Fix it.

Change-Id: I2cd39c5c01995b3e6cf22616c5343d8e1c4ce43b

that's new behavior they have to start using.
