subject: Blacklist oslo.serialization 2.19.1
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-07-17 20:17:16.000000000', 'files': ['global-requirements.txt'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/0948da6f05d12e2caf48dd70cc330cbd13311e57', 'message': "Blacklist oslo.serialization 2.19.1

Change If9e8dd5cc2634168910d5f9f8d9302aeefa16097 went into
2.19.1 which makes jsonutils.to_primitive() raise a ValueError
where before it would simply ignore an object it didn't know
how to convert to a primitive. This caused failures in Nova
tests and therefore pointed out how it's really an API change
in how to_primitive() works.

A revert in change Ibbfde6207fc8c066155758c7c1aa1521b95d4db1
will be released and then a UserWarning will be put in place
for this situation for a release before it goes back to raising
ValueError, so at least there is some time to let people handle
the warning.

Change-Id: I8cc26b612bf7b248dce625255266dce4401468a3
Related-Bug: #1593641
"}]
commit_message:
Blacklist oslo.serialization 2.19.1

Change If9e8dd5cc2634168910d5f9f8d9302aeefa16097 went into
2.19.1 which makes jsonutils.to_primitive() raise a ValueError
where before it would simply ignore an object it didn't know
how to convert to a primitive. This caused failures in Nova
tests and therefore pointed out how it's really an API change
in how to_primitive() works.

A revert in change Ibbfde6207fc8c066155758c7c1aa1521b95d4db1
will be released and then a UserWarning will be put in place
for this situation for a release before it goes back to raising
ValueError, so at least there is some time to let people handle
the warning.

Change-Id: I8cc26b612bf7b248dce625255266dce4401468a3
Related-Bug: #1593641

subject: fix test_volume_swap_server instability
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-07-17 08:38:22.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/functional/notification_sample_tests/test_instance.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/cf7f61c180c294f533e228697885a0ffb7e429bc', 'message': 'fix test_volume_swap_server instability

The test_volume_swap_server notification sample test was unstable
becase sometimes volume_swap.end notification was missing. The test was
waiting for the new volume id to appear on the REST API before
asserting the received notifications but the compute manager updates
the BDM earlier and then emits the volume_swap.end.

This patch modifies the test to explicitly wait for the
volume_swap.end notification. This expected to remove the test
instability.

Change-Id: Id6eefa7c85c4f63562344b552f027f1d513a90e1
Closes-Bug: #1704392
'}]
commit_message:
fix test_volume_swap_server instability

The test_volume_swap_server notification sample test was unstable
becase sometimes volume_swap.end notification was missing. The test was
waiting for the new volume id to appear on the REST API before
asserting the received notifications but the compute manager updates
the BDM earlier and then emits the volume_swap.end.

This patch modifies the test to explicitly wait for the
volume_swap.end notification. This expected to remove the test
instability.

Change-Id: Id6eefa7c85c4f63562344b552f027f1d513a90e1
Closes-Bug: #1704392
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/88/484288/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(gibi): the new volume id can appear on the API earlier than the # volume_swap.end notification emitted. So to make the test stable # we have to wait for the volume_swap.end notification directly. self._wait_for_notification('instance.volume_swap.end')

commit_message:
Replace six.iteritems() with .items()

1.As mentioned in [1], we should avoid using
six.iteritems to achieve iterators. We can
use dict.items instead, as it will return
iterators in PY3 as well. And dict.items/keys
will more readable. 2.In py2, the performance
about list should be negligible, see the link [2].
[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/066391.html

Change-Id: I32fe61cd768403ea9c4c8a1a0a6e011df0eafbbe
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/15/449915/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: resp = dict((k.lower(), v) for k, v in resp.items())
deleted_lines: import six resp = dict((k.lower(), v) for k, v in six.iteritems(resp))

commit_message:
Replace uuid.uuid4().hex with uuidutils.generate_uuid()

Openstack common has a wrapper for generating uuids.
We should use that function to generate uuids for consistency.

Change-Id: I65035b49a12c4be3a212eff3b89416bc8e20b77d

subject: Make get_email() work with python3
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-07-14 02:08:06.000000000', 'files': ['openstack_election/utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/election/commit/c217a1db8bd17fc023e809a8cafcdcf925316b31', 'message': "Make get_email() work with python3

If you try to build the docs with python3 you'll see something ending
with:
    ValueError: Couldn't find gerrit account with 'b'dmccowan@cisco.com''

This is because the default encoding from subprocess.Popen() under
python3 is bytes() which then fails to work with the gerrit API.

Check we have a text_type and decode() if needed.

Change-Id: Iccbc891a33d15ef82ddbc913549e64547a967195
"}]
commit_message:
Make get_email() work with python3

If you try to build the docs with python3 you'll see something ending
with:
    ValueError: Couldn't find gerrit account with 'b'dmccowan@cisco.com''

This is because the default encoding from subprocess.Popen() under
python3 is bytes() which then fails to work with the gerrit API.

Check we have a text_type and decode() if needed.

Change-Id: Iccbc891a33d15ef82ddbc913549e64547a967195
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/election refs/changes/28/483728/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import six email = git.stdout.readlines()[-1][:-1] # Force to text_type in py2 or py3 if isinstance(email, six.text_type): return email else: return email.decode('utf-8')

commit_message:
Update email address for Vladimir Kuklin

At the time od election Vladimir used the @mirantis address.  Since
then that email address has been removed from gerrit.  Using the REST
api we can confirm that the account that uploaded that review matches
the new email address.
 ---
 [tony@thor ~]$ curl https://review.openstack.org/changes/?q=I8d4fba4f2c39bf0542c79e9999a3face2261f2ce
 )]}'

     "branch": "master",

commit_message:
opensuse-minimal: install glibc-locale

We expect LC_ALL for non-C locales to be working inside
images, so always install glibc-locale for openSUSE.

Change-Id: I8fe92773e377539070d9d9fe2960a6202bb80a18

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-07-17 18:34:03.000000000', 'files': ['swift/obj/reconstructor.py', 'test/unit/obj/test_reconstructor.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/a876f92bbd2826adc6040b2e807826a3c01d8b4f', 'message': 'Avoid deleting new per disk reconstructor stats when aggregating

Previously the aggregate_recon_update might erase concurrently written
per disk recon cache stats from a slow worker, because unreported

during the first reconstruction cycles of the workers after startup or

commit_message:
Avoid deleting new per disk reconstructor stats when aggregating

Previously the aggregate_recon_update might erase concurrently written
per disk recon cache stats from a slow worker, because unreported
local devices were included in the clear_update. This could only occur
during the first reconstruction cycles of the workers after startup or
a ring change.

Now clear_update only has devices not found in all_local_devices.

Adds a unit test for the potential race.

Change-Id: I2021a6965c1096e6c2e165c7a867bc2491070253
Related-Change: I28925a37f3985c9082b5a06e76af4dc3ec813abe

commit_message:
Fix an issue of database migration

We did not migrate all old atomic to new format, just convert
them while getting data from database and update, so it maybe
occur an error while merging aotmic at line #104. I think it
is the time that we update all old atomic to new format, and
remove the lazy-migration.
NOTE:
It is ok to modify existing migration, since we have 2 cases:
1) the database doesn't include results in old format. In this case the
   old migration succedded and change of it doesn't affect anything.
   Everything is ok here
2) the database includes results in old format. In this case the old
   migration will fail and do not actually apply, so it will be possible
   to apply it again(with new code)

Change-Id: Idb2a0ffd161163537e62ced320f8da033f4e04c9

commit_message:
Fix N536 - Use assertIsNone regex

self.assertEqual((None, None), A) is valid since (None, None) is not
None. However assert_equal_none recognizes it as invalid.

Solution: Add '$' (Match the end of the text) with/without comment ( |\t)*#.*)?
to the regular expressions which intent to match None at the end of string.

Change-Id: Ic5e5c16c9225a80b2765a1d3cde9a5b9e83a06fb

commit_message:
Add Agilio OVS VIF and virtio-forwarder VNIC type

* This patch adds the necessary metadata for Nova to provide plugging
  for the external Agilio OVS ML2 and OS-VIF plugins.

  * A VIF type for Agilio OVS is added: this is used by the external
    ML2/mechanism plugin to trigger Nova to call the external OS-VIF
    plugin.

  * A virtio-forwarder VNIC type is added. This corresponds to a
    low-latency vhost-user forwarding process connecting an accelerated
    VF to a VM. This VNIC type is not intended to be specific to
    Agilio OVS.

  * The necessary end-to-end implementation has been verified, with the
    external plugin hosted at:
    https://github.com/Netronome/agilio-ovs-openstack-plugin

Change-Id: I28315fb12f62dc7d52d099c211086b2b81eca39a
Signed-off-by: Jan Gutter <jan.gutter@netronome.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib refs/changes/30/483530/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

In addition to the normal OVS # vif types exposed, VNIC_DIRECT and # VNIC_VIRTIO_FORWARDER are supported. VIF_TYPE_AGILIO_OVS = 'agilio_ovs'VNIC_VIRTIO_FORWARDER = 'virtio-forwarder' VNIC_DIRECT_PHYSICAL, VNIC_VIRTIO_FORWARDER]

commit_message:
[placement] Update allocation-candidates.yaml for gabbi 1.35

Gabbi 1.35 provides template variable susbtitution on the left hand side
of a JSONPath expression. That's used here to remove the need for static
fake uuids in the test data for allocation-candidates and the
SharedStorageFixture.

A couple of other clean ups to the use of gabbi, unrelated to the 1.35
update:

* It's possible to test the entire value in one response:

    resources:
         VCPU: 4
         DISK_GB: 5

  instead of:

    resources.VCPU: 4
    resources.DISK_GB: 5

  This is handy when the root of the expression is calculated and
  repeating that calculation is noisy.

* [?foo.bar=baz] is the more canonical form of [?(@.foo.bar=baz)]. The
  former is built into jsonpath, the latter dips into the underlying
  implementation.

Change-Id: Ie6b5e0186533581815d04411ed7b321948464bb6

commit_message:
Build Common Framework for Feature Classification Matrix

The feature classification matrix will provide information about
plugins and the features they support. Acts as a launching point for
users to ready to deploy their cloud. Users can use the matrix to find
features and plugins that meet their
needs.

Pulling out the framework from Nova's implementation here:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/support-matrix.html

Neutron and Nova are currently working on implementation.

Putting the extension in its own module will give all projects a common
framework to use.

Change-Id: I74f4da4f150ba691bfa8b440c073b7a9da282259
Co-Authored-By: <ankur.gupta@intel.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sphinx-feature-classification refs/changes/24/484524/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Sphinx Configuration ==================== To use the extension, add ``'sphinx-feature-classificiation'`` to the ``extensions`` list in the ``conf.py`` file in your Sphinx project. Documenting Your Drivers ======================== 1. This extension uses an ini file to render your driver matrix in Sphinx. You can begin by creating the file support-matrix.ini file in your sphinx's source directory. 2. Start by creating a [targets] section. Each new line item in this section will represent a driver in our matrix. In the example below, we use a mandatory prefix 'driver-impl-' followed by the name of the driver. This is then set to a friendly name of the driver. This variable will be used throughout the ini file to identify if this particular driver supports a project's feature. .. code-block:: INI [targets] driver-impl-xenserver=XenServer driver-impl-libvirt-kvm-x86=Libvirt KVM (x86) 3. Next we'll create a feature section to show which drivers support it. .. code-block:: INI [operation.attach-volume] title=Attach block volume to instance status=optional notes=The attach volume operation provides a means to hotplug additional block storage to a running instance. cli=nova volume-attach <server> <volume> driver-impl-xenserver=complete driver-impl-libvirt-kvm-x86=complete The 'status' field takes possible values * mandatory - unconditionally required to be implemented * optional - optional to support, nice to have * choice(group) - at least one of the options within the named group must be implemented * condition - required, if the referenced condition is met. The value against each 'driver-impl-XXXX' entry refers to the level of the implementation of the feature in that driver * complete - fully implemented, expected to work at all times * partial - implemented, but with caveats about when it will work eg some configurations or hardware or guest OS may not support it * missing - not implemented at all
deleted_lines: To use sphinx-feature-classificiation in a project:: import sphinx_feature_classification

commit_message:
[db] optimize obtaining task object

Let's use join to grep the detailed task object by one db call instead
of multiple calls.

Also, in terms of task update action, we do not need to grep task
object from the database.

Change-Id: Iad9715c166dd13a0670d4badbbcdc3987ba4667f

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-07-13 17:32:59.000000000', 'files': ['container-images/tripleo_kolla_template_overrides.j2'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common/commit/b43e212b3bb8ce4cd3cd50f4bf4e97135e43a934', 'message': "Remove EPEL in TripleO's Kolla template_overrides

Kolla has been trying to remove EPEL as a dependency from their
base container image but it turns out it's not so simple [1] and could
potentially take until Queens.

RDO does not require EPEL since Mitaka and can only cause problems

Change-Id: Ib235810a2d2776708a352d117a4a85075424e33d

commit_message:
Remove EPEL in TripleO's Kolla template_overrides

Kolla has been trying to remove EPEL as a dependency from their
base container image but it turns out it's not so simple [1] and could
potentially take until Queens.

RDO does not require EPEL since Mitaka and can only cause problems
for us in the long run so let's remove it.

[1]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/474999/

Change-Id: Ib235810a2d2776708a352d117a4a85075424e33d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/73/483473/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix python 3.6 escape char warnings in strings

In python 3.6, escape sequences that are not
recognized in string literals issue DeprecationWarnings.

Convert these to raw strings.

Change-Id: I0d20a0dd27415eab0abf08ceb5be415ae1cf0ad0

WIP - attempt at including /etc/monasca-transform.conf, but

Change-Id: I7a1dd98b66a3c74f6ec1ad71394351e328f7bc7b

commit_message:
WIP Add monasca-transform

Include monasca-transform, the aggregation engine for Monasca.
Also requires Apache Spark to be packaged.

Note that the name of the monasca_transform directory in the
.tgz includes an _ and thus doesn't match the sname which
has a -.

Specifying a Requires: spark == 1.6.3, which has to be provided
separately.

WIP - all the files in correct location?
WIP - install and config scripts (reference devstack/plugin.sh)
WIP - Spark - need to create a separate package for 1.6.3
WIP - attempt at including /etc/monasca-transform.conf, but
      what is up with python-monasca-tranform?

Change-Id: I7a1dd98b66a3c74f6ec1ad71394351e328f7bc7b

commit_message:
[ci] do not fail on glance resources

Glance has an issue with integration with uwsgi. Since OpenStack
community has a global goal - move everyone under uwsgi, glance team
cannot just revert moving under uwsgi, so we need to wait.

Since we do not want to be blocked due to such kind of issues, let's
skip the case when glance resources are not deleted.

Change-Id: I0a8c5d8867f6b43b80a97c2eeda3cefb9f02dd4d

commit_message:
WIP: Call preallocate_for_instance before scheduler

Later we want to use information from preallocate_for_instance to work
out what IP address resources each instance will need. For now, we just
add the call to preallocate_for_instance, which must pass information
to allocate_for_instance. This is needed to ensure if we create the
ports early on in the build process, we don't created them a second time
later on in the build process.

Note: this also make use of the fact that preallocate_for_instance
does not modify the requsted_networks objects that are passed in,
otherwise this would be even more confusing.

We could replace requested networks objects with the new
processed_networks objects, but for that we will need a major version
bump of the interface. So for now we pass both of them, and leave the
rest of the tidy up for later (probably want nova-network is killed).

TODO - schedule_and_build_instances got added during a rebase with
throws a spanner in this first attempt, grrrr

blueprint prep-for-network-aware-scheduling-pike

Change-Id: I0af09f1007889755134d96ec2ded6e9374385102

deleted_lines: block_device_mapping=None, node=None, limits=None): version = '4.0' cctxt = self.router.by_host(ctxt, host).prepare( server=host, version=version) limits=limits)

commit_message:
WIP: Add processed_requests to allocate_for_instance

So we can optionally call preallocate_for_instance before calling
allocate_for_instance, ensure allocate_for_instance can take the new
param processed_requests, a instance of ProcessedNetworkRequestList that
contains all the state from preallocate_for_instance.

When a ProcessedNetworkRequestList is passed into the neutron API, we
simply skip the call to preallocate_for_instance.

blueprint prep-for-network-aware-scheduling-pike

Change-Id: I096ef4736da39a124fb283d85a58662865bfafb3

commit_message:
WIP: introduce preallocate_for_instance method.

This is a no-op for nova-network, and is a rename of
_validate_req_and_create_ports for neutron.

This will get called before doing any scheduling to make sure all the
ports are created, and we have the information on the network segments
and what ips are needed before we do any scheduling.

blueprint prep-for-network-aware-scheduling-pike

Change-Id: Id5aa3d0fc37ed7f905614f1d1d07b7791e36d003
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/81/418881/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def preallocate_for_instance(self, context, instance, requested_networks, security_groups): """Does initial network setup, before picking a host, like port create :param context: The request context. :param instance: objects.Instance object. :param requested_networks: object.NetworkRequestList object. :param security_groups: None or security groups to allocate for instance. :returns: object.ProcessedNetworkRequestList """ raise NotImplementedError()

subject: Fix no networks preallocate_for_instance return
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-01-13 14:08:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/8e40c9b49e3ff089180a14c886fc748ed7797395', 'message': 'Fix no networks preallocate_for_instance return

When preallocate_for_instance decides there are is no network, and that
is a valid request, we now return the ProcessedNetworkRequestList
instead of None.

In this patch we stop _validate_requested_network_ids from returning any
values, as all the information is in the ProcessedNetworkRequestList
object.

commit_message:
Fix no networks preallocate_for_instance return

When preallocate_for_instance decides there are is no network, and that
is a valid request, we now return the ProcessedNetworkRequestList
instead of None.

In this patch we stop _validate_requested_network_ids from returning any
values, as all the information is in the ProcessedNetworkRequestList
object.

blueprint prep-for-network-aware-scheduling-pike

Change-Id: Ic80454c82584c4354b0ebdbd7edd1c8230db90af

commit_message:
Tidy up preallocate_for_instance

There are a few loose ends from the refactor, this patch completes a few
of those by removing return values and method parameters that are no
longer required.

blueprint prep-for-network-aware-scheduling-pike

Change-Id: I00f2255b08b86dc3d14add6cfbb4dbfb8d76678d

commit_message:
Extract preallocate_for_instance

This is the method that will eventually be called before calling the
scheduler and before calling allocate_for_instance. As such it returns a
versioned object, so the value can one day go across RPC.

blueprint prep-for-network-aware-scheduling-pike

Change-Id: I8fd586b3e886a81daa5c446bf58ac8cf41647409
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/76/418876/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def preallocate_for_instance(self, context, instance, requested_networks, security_groups, neutron=None): """Does initial network setup, before picking a host, like port create :param context: The request context. :param instance: objects.Instance object. :param requested_networks: object.NetworkRequestList object. :param security_groups: None or security groups for instance. :param neutron: authenticated instance of NeutronClient :returns: object.ProcessedNetworkRequestList """ LOG.debug('preallocate_for_instance()', instance=instance) if not neutron: neutron = get_client(context) # # Validate ports and networks with neutron # processed_requests = self._validate_requested_port_ids( context, instance, neutron, requested_networks) # TODO(johngarbutt) fake ports return value to make this # change as small as possible. Remove in follow up change. ordered_networks = [] for processed in processed_requests: if processed.network_id: ordered_networks.append(processed.request) # TODO(johngarbutt) stop passing ordered networks when not used # by create_ports_for_instance nets = self._validate_requested_network_ids( context, instance, neutron, processed_requests, ordered_networks) if not nets: # skip port create, as no networks configured return processed_requests # # Create any ports that might be required, # after validating requested security groups # security_groups = self._clean_security_groups(security_groups) security_group_ids = self._process_security_groups( instance, neutron, security_groups) # TODO(johngarbutt) stop returning requests_and_created_ports self._create_ports_for_instance(context, instance, processed_requests, neutron, security_group_ids) return processed_requests # TODO(johngarbutt) skip this method if already called, and the # processed_requests object is passed into this method. processed_requests = self.preallocate_for_instance( context, instance, requested_networks, security_groups, neutron) if len(processed_requests) == 0: LOG.debug("No network configured", instance=instance) return network_model.NetworkInfo([])
deleted_lines: # # Validate ports and networks with neutron # processed_requests = self._validate_requested_port_ids( context, instance, neutron, requested_networks) ordered_networks = [] for processed in processed_requests: if processed.network_id: ordered_networks.append(processed.request) # TODO(johngarbutt) stop passing ordered networks when not used # by create_ports_for_instance nets = self._validate_requested_network_ids( context, instance, neutron, processed_requests, ordered_networks) if not nets: LOG.debug("No network configured", instance=instance) return network_model.NetworkInfo([]) # # Create any ports that might be required, # after validating requested security groups # security_groups = self._clean_security_groups(security_groups) security_group_ids = self._process_security_groups( instance, neutron, security_groups) # TODO(johngarbutt) stop returning requests_and_created_ports self._create_ports_for_instance(context, instance, processed_requests, neutron, security_group_ids)

commit_message:
Pass objects into _update_ports_for_instance

Before we can split out all the code before _update_ports_for_instance
into a separate method that returns the new object, we must ensure
_update_ports_for_instance takes the new object

blueprint prep-for-network-aware-scheduling-pike

Change-Id: Ica04fb38acb39d7a1494d2a1c64c44a20a7a28b4

commit_message:
Stop passing network when you only need dns_domain

For helper functions in _update_ports_for_instance, lets be sure only to
pass the dns domain, rather the network object, so it will be easier to
move to the new ProcessedNetworkRequestList object.

blueprint prep-for-network-aware-scheduling-ocata

Change-Id: Ifabf5cbaefe719054ec8979cc2532f141f9ff1ed

commit_message:
Pass objects into _create_ports_for_instance

Pass the new ProcessedNetworkRequestList object into
_create_ports_for_instance and populate the ProcessedNetworkRequestList
with information on the created ports.

For that to work, we also need to populate network information inside
the _validate_requested_network_ids method.

blueprint prep-for-network-aware-scheduling-pike

Change-Id: I5141a90542b80ba3da07275059779ebc659d78ff

commit_message:
Pass objects into _validate_requested_network_ids

So we can pass from the network validation into the port create, first
start passing in the ProcessedNetworkRequestList object into
_validate_requested_network_ids.

blueprint prep-for-network-aware-scheduling-pike

Change-Id: Ia889ff0d2df5b2b4443c63623335ad8b9ff3b976

commit_message:
Add and use ProcessedNetworkRequest object

This adds new ProcessedNetworkRequest and ProcessedNetworkRequestList
objects and starts using them in _validate_requested_port_ids.

The plan here to eventually pass a ProcessedNetworkRequestList object
into allocate_for_instance to skip the port create step. That object
will have been generated by code that has run earlier in the instance
build flow, before we call the scheduler. Because this state will flow
over the RPC interface, eventually, we need an o.vo.

The refactoring here is trying to ensure we can extract all the logic in
allocate_for_instance up to and including _create_ports_for_instance
into a method that can be called earlier in the instance build process.
This is just the first step in that process.

There are a lot of unit test changes here to ensure we don't pass
invalid mac addresses, because this would fail the unit tests now we are
using an o.vo field of type mac address.

blueprint prep-for-network-aware-scheduling-pike

Change-Id: Iab6299538a4b3f852957143ea42ebb505020a4ff
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/25/418025/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Updated api-ref with more details on net-mtu extension

While at it, changed sample responses to more sane mtu values that
should reflect the default neutron behaviour unless mtu configuration
options are touched. In one instance, replaced an 'stt' segment with a
'vxlan' one since there is no 'stt' type driver, at least not in the
neutron core repository.

Change-Id: I3c6506f372173cb9c778c5d83f1df45da611dcf2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib refs/changes/72/483072/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Add support for shared "backend_defaults" config
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-29 04:24:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/768b9fda76be07b0bd115fef53d45379c1f38512', 'message': 'Add support for shared "backend_defaults" config

This gives a new config section that is shared for
all enabled_backends in a cinder.conf. This is optional
but can be used like:

[DEFAULT]
...
enabled_backends=lvm-1,lvm-2
...

[backend_defaults]
image_volume_cache_enabled = True
volume_clear = none
iscsi_helper = tgtadm
volume_driver = cinder.volume.drivers.lvm.LVMVolumeDriver

[lvm-1]
volume_group = stack-volumes-lvm-1

[lvm-2]
volume_group = stack-volumes-lvmd-2
lvm_type = thin

This also sets up the config helper to be easily
refactored to remove support for DEFAULT stanza
configured backends.

DocImpact: Need to document upgrade path and new
recommended config.
Implements: blueprint shared-backend-config

commit_message:
Add support for shared "backend_defaults" config

This gives a new config section that is shared for
all enabled_backends in a cinder.conf. This is optional
but can be used like:

[DEFAULT]
...
enabled_backends=lvm-1,lvm-2
...

[backend_defaults]
image_volume_cache_enabled = True
volume_clear = none
iscsi_helper = tgtadm
volume_driver = cinder.volume.drivers.lvm.LVMVolumeDriver

[lvm-1]
volume_group = stack-volumes-lvm-1

[lvm-2]
volume_group = stack-volumes-lvmd-2
lvm_type = thin

This also sets up the config helper to be easily
refactored to remove support for DEFAULT stanza
configured backends.

DocImpact: Need to document upgrade path and new
recommended config.
Implements: blueprint shared-backend-config
Change-Id: I2f94118b32076f264b3cf21caa259785fd415167
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/99/335299/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: SHARED_CONF_GROUP = 'backend_defaults' class DefaultGroupConfiguration(object): """Get config options from only DEFAULT TODO: This class may be removed once we no longer support backend configs in the DEFAULT section. For now this remains to support backwards compatibility through the deprecation process. """ def __init__(self): self.local_conf = CONF CONF.register_opts(volume_opts, group=None) class BackendGroupConfiguration(object): def __init__(self, volume_opts, config_group=None): """Initialize configuration. This takes care of grafting the implementation's config values into the config group and shared defaults. We will try to pull values from the specified 'config_group', but fall back to defaults from the SHARED_CONF_GROUP. """ self.config_group = config_group # set the local conf so that __call__'s know what to use self._ensure_config_values(volume_opts) self.backend_conf = CONF._get(self.config_group) self.shared_backend_conf = CONF._get(SHARED_CONF_GROUP) def _ensure_config_values(self, volume_opts): """Register the options in the shared group. When we go to get a config option we will try the backend specific group first and fall back to the shared group. We override the default from all the config options for the backend group so we can know if it was set or not. """ for opt in volume_opts: try: CONF.register_opt(opt, group=SHARED_CONF_GROUP) except cfg.DuplicateOptError: continue # If it's already registered ignore it CONF.register_opts(volume_opts, group=self.config_group) for opt in volume_opts: # Later we look for None to know if we should fall back to the # shared defaults group with the *real* default values. CONF.set_default(opt.name, None, group=self.config_group) def append_config_values(self, volume_opts): self._ensure_config_values(volume_opts) def safe_get(self, value): try: return self.__getattr__(value) except cfg.NoSuchOptError: return None def __getattr__(self, opt_name): # Don't use self.X to avoid reentrant call to __getattr__() backend_conf = object.__getattribute__(self, 'backend_conf') opt_value = getattr(backend_conf, opt_name) if opt_value is None: shared_conf = object.__getattribute__(self, 'shared_backend_conf') opt_value = getattr(shared_conf, opt_name) return opt_value class Configuration(object): def __init__(self, volume_opts, config_group=None): """Initialize configuration. This shim will allow for compatibility with the deprecated DEFAULT style of backend configuration. TODO: Once we can remove DefaultGroupConfiguration we should rename BackendGroupConfiguration to Configuration and delete this shim. """ self.config_group = config_group if config_group: self.conf = BackendGroupConfiguration(volume_opts, config_group) else: self.conf = DefaultGroupConfiguration() def append_config_values(self, volume_opts): self.conf.append_config_values(volume_opts) def safe_get(self, value): return self.conf.safe_get(value) def __getattr__(self, value): # Don't use self.conf to avoid reentrant call to __getattr__() conf = object.__getattribute__(self, 'conf') return getattr(conf, value)
deleted_lines: class Configuration(object): def __init__(self, volume_opts, config_group=None): """Initialize configuration. This takes care of grafting the implementation's config values into the config group """ self.config_group = config_group if self.config_group: self._ensure_config_values(volume_opts) self.local_conf = CONF._get(self.config_group) else: self.local_conf = CONF CONF.register_opts(volume_opts, group=self.config_group)

commit_message:
Add event definition for manila

Since the ceilometer integration has been merged in Manila
(https://review.openstack.org/#/c/466586/) and
some work has been done for the Manila ceilometer metrics
(https://review.openstack.org/#/c/472752/), this
commit is for having the notification defined by default so we can get
all the fields from the Manila notification

Change-Id: I1050bf8d7d62fc75cfd7d800921122eb25be5c5b

commit_message:
Move virtual interfaces test into misc policy actions file

Move test_list_virtual_interfaces into
test_server_misc_policy_actions_rbac.py to further increase gate
stability and decrease gate run time.

The number of calls to create_test_server() should be minimized
for RBAC testing because we don't do too much modification to the
resources that are created -- only what's necessary to trigger the
API action corresponding to the RBAC policy under test. Further,
minimizing such calls reduces the risk of spinning up too many servers
concurrently in our gates: the source of various gate failures as
limited resources lead to server faults being raised.

Change-Id: I1ff0c14e741c8907f2f23a4dd63705713f06d337
Partial-Bug: #1699415

commit_message:
CI/scenarios: set NotificationDriver to 'noop'

So we don't waste RabbitMQ resources since nothing will actually consume
the messages sent on the queue.

Note: we don't change scenario001, since it's a Telemetry scenario and
the services require notifications enabled.

Change-Id: I7d1d80da4eda7c0385461fe62b1d3038022973c6

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary variables in UT

In unit tests of API definition, there are extension_resources which
defines core resources although they are not resources of extension.
This patch removes them.

TrivialFix

subject: Don't access connection.info if connection is invalidated
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-07-14 20:17:26.000000000', 'files': ['oslo_db/sqlalchemy/exc_filters.py', 'oslo_db/tests/sqlalchemy/test_exc_filters.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.db/commit/7c5b7d3e035859fd08946e031e62cc4abfe683f0', 'message': "Don't access connection.info if connection is invalidated

The connection.info dictionary comes from the underlying
pooled connection, which in a disconnection situation
is not there; trying to access it makes it try to reconnect.
Inside of rollback(), SQLAlchemy doesn't allow us to
reconnect yet because we haven't finished removing the
transctional state that corresponds to the now-discarded
connection.  Therefore we have to check connection.invalidated
inside of our rollback handlers before trying to add/remove tokens
from connection.info.

Change-Id: Icd10ada68d6d53410ac88eca3577f04c5e30087e
Resolves-bug: #1704474
"}]
commit_message:
Don't access connection.info if connection is invalidated

The connection.info dictionary comes from the underlying
pooled connection, which in a disconnection situation
is not there; trying to access it makes it try to reconnect.
Inside of rollback(), SQLAlchemy doesn't allow us to
reconnect yet because we haven't finished removing the
transctional state that corresponds to the now-discarded
connection.  Therefore we have to check connection.invalidated
inside of our rollback handlers before trying to add/remove tokens
from connection.info.

Change-Id: Icd10ada68d6d53410ac88eca3577f04c5e30087e
Resolves-bug: #1704474
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.db refs/changes/35/484035/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Set fixed-key key manager

With the key manager refactoring in nova and cinder, the key manager
class will need to be explicitly set.

Nova key manager refactoring: Ib563b0ea4b8b4bc1833bf52bf49a68546c384996
Cinder key manager refactoring: Ief8885bb4ca8d62b03cf1a52c25dd0e62c835bfe

Change-Id: I733279864ee1a4aaffc9c8eed81b5e12f8d8821b
Implements: blueprint use-castellan-key-manager

commit_message:
Fix the update of qos-policy

Update qos-policy without rules was ending in error
because in helper method for converting policy data
for odl a check before poping a key was missing.

Change-Id: Id7da3b95c4160176a8a400888563e6405d57d5b1
Closes-Bug: #1642680
(cherry picked from commit b12a243fa53f6b7920d1bb05c472779bd6fd3c84)

full_sync: sync router before port

port references to port via device owner. so sync router before
port.

commit_message:
Add table_actions_menu for Environments Table

Now there are too many actions for the Environments table,
we can use table_actions_menu fuction to add some of the actions to the
More Actions menu, this can reduce the lenth of the table actions.

Change-Id: If1dd94f737f2e893e5d40492b1f8a65d5fc81d36

commit_message:
Turn on warning-is-error for sphinx build

The doc-migration spec requires all projects to treat warnings
as errors during sphinx build. This patches turns that function
on and resolves the error (detailed below) coming as a result
of it.

The code block in event_concept.rst file is currently made to
render in javascript which is an incorrect syntax for it.

Change-Id: Id7fee247b76ed7cfebb849305e0611bc966709be

Fix redundant UTF-8 check

In the file proxy/server.py, handle_request method does UTF-8
check twice. This patch is to fix it.

Change-Id: I6db742bce6fa4fa9e935b15460037e0ec90e9373
Closes-Bug: #1704539

commit_message:
Fixed AttributeError in l2pop.delete_port_postcommit

The error sneaked in with Ib6e59ab3405857d3ed4d82df1a80800089c3f06e
where is_ha_router_port expects a NeutronContext object but we still
pass PortContext instead.

Change-Id: I593af5d050de00ddea7d758007d9856c4b97695f
Closes-Bug: #1703938

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-14 22:32:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b474c28318feda48c4c925f2216eecf7323356b3', 'message': 'Add Cinder v3 detach to swap_volume

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-04-20 18:18:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/91dee482d4aeb0345df22b95a229e027ccdd306c', 'message': 'Add Cinder v3 detach to swap_volume

'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2017-04-24 00:55:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/1b26d2418269279096cb36d7c78e4aeb3aa1355e', 'message': "WIP: Add Cinder v3 detach to swap_volume

This adds the support for new style volume attachments
to the swap volume operation.

If the existing volume attachment (old_volume) was created
using the new flow, it will have attachment_id set. Based
on that the API will create a new volume attachment for the
volume being swapped to and then pass that attachment to the
compute over RPC. Note that we do not yet create new-style
volume attachments so this is all no-op code for now. And
when we do start creating new-style volume attachments, that
will only be allowed when Cinder is new enough (3.27 microversion)
and all compute services are upgraded, so we don't perform
any nova-compute service version checks here.

Once on the compute, we key off the new_attachment_id being
passed from the API to tell if we should use the old or new
style calls to Cinder. For example, initialize_connection and
terminate_connection are replaced with attachment_update and
attachment_delete.

Partially Implements: blueprint cinder-new-attach-apis

Change-Id: I4b8bd01f1ffe2640fe7313213bf853d2e1bef9dd

commit_message:
Handle Cinder 3.27 style attachments in swap_volume

This adds the support for new style volume attachments
to the swap volume operation.

If the existing volume attachment (old_volume) was created
using the new flow, it will have attachment_id set. Based
on that the API will create a new volume attachment for the
volume being swapped to and then pass that attachment to the
compute over RPC. Note that we do not yet create new-style
volume attachments so this is all no-op code for now. And
when we do start creating new-style volume attachments, that
will only be allowed when Cinder is new enough (3.27 microversion)
and all compute services are upgraded, so we don't perform
any nova-compute service version checks here.

Once on the compute, we key off the new_attachment_id being
passed from the API to tell if we should use the old or new
style calls to Cinder. For example, initialize_connection and
terminate_connection are replaced with attachment_update and
attachment_delete.

Co-Authored-By: Matt Riedemann <mriedem.os@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: John Griffith <john.griffith8@gmail.com>

Depends-On: I23391300468cc5e2f45a12d5ad8617ab48c21e6a

Partially Implements: blueprint cinder-new-attach-apis

Change-Id: I4b8bd01f1ffe2640fe7313213bf853d2e1bef9dd

commit_message:
VMAX - Live Migration, replacing SMI-S with REST

In VMAX driver version 3.0, SMI-S has been replaced with unisphere
REST. This is porting Live Migration from SMIS to REST.
See original https://review.openstack.org/#/c/450430/ for more
details.

Change-Id: I7e0d9cc382a75148ecd53c48f8b2e4e69a68163c
Partially-Implements: blueprint vmax-rest

commit_message:
VMAX driver - Replication, replacing SMI-S with REST

In VMAX driver version 3.0, SMI-S has been replaced with unisphere
REST. This is porting Replication V2.1 from SMIS to REST.
See original https://review.openstack.org/#/c/409079/ for more
details

Change-Id: I9cb8d931bd40cb34429f228f1723bb162a75443f
Partially-Implements: blueprint vmax-rest
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/27/466027/36 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if workload and workload.lower() == 'none': workload = None if slo and slo.lower() == 'none': slo = None def break_rdf_relationship(self, array, device_id, target_device, rdf_group, rep_extra_specs, state): """Break the rdf relationship between a pair of devices. :param array: the array serial number :param device_id: the source device id :param target_device: target device id :param rdf_group: the rdf group number :param rep_extra_specs: replication extra specs :param state: the state of the rdf pair """ LOG.info("Splitting rdf pair: source device: %(src)s " "target device: %(tgt)s.", {'src': device_id, 'tgt': target_device}) if state == 'Synchronized': self.rest.modify_rdf_device_pair( array, device_id, rdf_group, rep_extra_specs, split=True) LOG.info("Deleting rdf pair: source device: %(src)s " "target device: %(tgt)s.", {'src': device_id, 'tgt': target_device}) self.rest.delete_rdf_pair(array, device_id, rdf_group) def failover_volume(self, array, device_id, rdf_group, extra_specs, state, failover): """Failover or back a volume pair. :param array: the array serial number :param device_id: the source device id :param rdf_group: the rdf group number :param extra_specs: extra specs :param state: the rdf state of the pair :param failover: flag to indicate failover or failback -- bool """ if failover: action = "Failing over" else: action = "Failing back" LOG.info("%(action)s rdf pair: source device: %(src)s ", {'action': action, 'src': device_id}) self.rest.modify_rdf_device_pair( array, device_id, rdf_group, extra_specs, split=False, failover=failover)
deleted_lines: if workload: if workload.lower() == 'none': workload = None

commit_message:
ScaleIO Driver: Fix transposing of PD and SP in list of pools

Protection Domain and Storage Pool names were transposed in list
of valid PD:SP names, which caused the driver to fail.

Change-Id: Ic925f2c4d78aa3ca72456990c97796822f4c004d

commit_message:
Reduce tools/image_list.sh down to 4 images

Now that mysql.qcow2 has been removed, we only have 4 images to worry
about. This fixes cache-devstack element for openstack-infra.

Change-Id: Ia06f0e0679e253a1a6614f7c38abf1f5cd13991b
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>
(Cherry-picked from 331b3de88e02d6cc480b386766f47b7a2d943125)

subject: Fix volume migration error with NEC driver
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-07-06 08:25:56.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/volume/drivers/nec/volume_common.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/58a8842e81e5ebaafd730dade1f8fe46ccdb42ae', 'message': 'Fix volume migration error with NEC driver

Fix volume migration error with multiple NEC Storage backends
by keeping ssh_conn_timeout parameter in local variable.

Change-Id: Ifb709b85374d1e1a844c3ff60952f85d1a8c4e5c
Closes-Bug: #1698328
'}]
commit_message:
Fix volume migration error with NEC driver

Fix volume migration error with multiple NEC Storage backends
by keeping ssh_conn_timeout parameter in local variable.
